Posts.Content: cheers Kacang  I'll have a read okay well that is quite comforting for those choosing to, or being strongly advised to, be treated with chemotherapy but it is just dealing with death in the first 30 days. It doesn't deal with long term side effects and the emotional effects or relationship stresses which we know happen more around chemotherapy than surgery alone for cancer patients.  The Predict Tool uses long term studies on substantial groups of women, some of whom must choose not to have chemo for primary early stage breast cancers, I was told that due to confidentiality I couldn't talk to any of those women, which is a little frustrating, I'd like to have real women talking about their decisions after 5 and 10 years anyway Predict is to allow both health professionals and patients to check the statistics  I still don't think everyone needs to have chemotherapy, i do think it is over used, the NHS thinks it's overused but guidelines say to offer it in borderline cases. using 70 as the age, routine screening, 20mm tumour, grade 2 and no lymph involvement, ER+ Her2- "Five year survival 90 out of 100 women are alive at 5 years with no adjuvant therapy after surgery  An extra 1 out of 100 women treated are alive because of hormone therapy  An extra 2 out of 100 women treated are alive because of hormone therapy & chemotherapy" personally I just don't think chemo is worth the risk in this scenario, in fact I'm not sure I'd even take the hormone therapy  NB  this is a estimate without correct information other than the age xx Carolyn

Posts.Content: hi Ronnie47  welcome to the online community, sorry you've had to come and find us it's always going to be a tricky decision for people like us to make because we have no experience or expertise have you been shown the Predict tool? you need to input your age at diagnosis , which you have given us, but you also need size of the lump and whether lymph nodes are involved http://predict.nhs.uk/predict_v2.0.html I tentatively put some 'average' values in to test it and chemo doesn't offer much benefit to you at your age Chemotherapy carries a risk and we seem to have adopted 3% because one lady's  oncologist was adamant that that was correct but I have heard 5% used That means that unless you can see a clear 5% benefit using the Predict tool putting your body (and mind) through chemo isn't worth it, the risks outweigh the benefits.  For me the uplift in stats was something like 25-30% so I was persuaded , I'm 55 now but was 52 at the time of diagnosis . hope that helps a bit ? Posts.Title: The gift that really does keep on giving!

Posts.Content: hi Mighty Mouse  someone else was saying that their surgeon needed needlework training, their seams weren't up to much, and I must admit my first mastectomy scar was so horrific I cried, it looked like I'd been in a terrible accident rather than a carefully planned operation. The implant was also too large but we've sorted that now and my scar is much better. I didn't have a diep so not really sure what to say to expect but one thing I will say is that mine did take an age to settle down. I had the surgery in July '15 and what with the seroma and part of the scar not closing properly, it didn't really settle until just before the revision surgery in March '16. Patience is a virtue. It took me a few months to be able to look at myself critically in the mirror but I've taken my fake boob to a few beaches now and it doesn't attract any attention. Almost all the surgeons I've spoken to are really painfully aware how critical we are, it's not just vanity, and I do believe they want us to be delighted with their efforts at reconstructing us after our cancer diagnosis, we want to appear as 'normal' as possible and be able to look at ourselves in the mirror, not just flaunt ourselves for others. I think my case was a little easier for me to deal with as I didn't have to put up any kind of fight or argument to get the revision surgery, they'd manage to miss a 15mm tumour during the mastectomy, really should have gone to specsavers, and were duty bound to go back in and retrieve what was left of it after chemo, which also gave them a chance to improve the scar. But don't feel bad, you are well within your rights to demand an improvement in aesthetics. Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi Jo we also have it in the family so I was resigned to it at some point, although the GP said it's not inevitable if you keep your weight stable and don't overload on sugars. The key thing I learned during the last pregnancy, when I was checking my blood regularly (6 times a day in the first couple of weeks) was that the body averages out the values. I found that if I had a 3 course meal, even if I had ice cream as a dessert, my blood sugar wouldn't spike. So I checked and it's true, your body does average it out. Eating a variety of foods is key to stable blood glucose. A glass of orange juice on its own will cause a spike but a cheese sandwich on wholemeal or oatmeal bread and a glass of orange juice won't. A bowl of porridge and a glass of orange juice won't, three rashers of bacon and two fried eggs and a glass of orange juice won't. But you have to try it for yourself. I have seen various splits but 30% protein, 30% fats and 30% carbs would seem logical but probably hard to keep up, I'm sure most people average more like 50% carbs, 30% protein and 20% fats.  I'm going to do a little more digging on this ratio. It's too simplistic to say eat a low carb diet because it's relative isn't it, you may already not be eating many carbs. But you may be snacking on fruit, better to have cheese and fruit, or cheese on a ryvita type snack bread and a bit of fruit. How do you feel about investing in a blood sugar monitoring kit ? Boots do some for around 20 quid.  Personally I see very little value in a fasting glucose test now I've experienced the regular blood sugar monitoring alongside your regular meals. most kits have a finger pricker which is spring loaded and painless, a set of test strips, which are then purchased as a consumable so check they stock supplies,  and a gadget that beeps and gives you the reading. plus alcohol wipes. Did you have a look at the glycaemic index ? hugs Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: Rich1984  hi, I agree with Misty to a certain extent but I have met women that totally rely on their husbands, how independent is your wife ? I had EC and T, other women have FEC and T.  Everyone reacts differently.  Normally we're given anti-sickness meds and a steroid before the infusion, it varies but not by much across the UK. Then there's the 'goody bag' of meds to take home.  One of my friends relied on her husband to pretty much take over her care, now that's not something I'd do but in my marriage we're debating who's going to end up in prison for killing whom. I've been reliably informed that no jury would ever convict me, but the kids asked me not to so I've packed away the lead pipe and the candlestick. I'm sure my current husband would have relished the opportunity to finish me off if I'd allowed him access to the goody bag. However, the sickness meds did work for me, I had Ondansetron and was told to take one after a few hours, once the injection had worn off.  Other people prefer or have more luck with Emend. Getting the drugs right and in the right dose takes a bit of trial and error. Then there's the steroids , I had dexamethasone, as an injection before the infusion and tablets to take the next day. That was more than enough for me to cope with but then I was up at 3am with diarrhea and again at 4 ... and 5 and 6 ...  so I took some of the codeine I had left from my surgery and that helped.  Then I had to deal with constipation which is either tinned peaches or another drug, I think Dulcolax seemed to have been mentioned as the most reliable but prunes, plums or any stoned fruit are very good and avoids a drug overload. It's a lot to take in and nobody is going to condemn you for throwing up your arms in despair, just as long as you have a good wail then get a grip.  I had to make a list and re-read the leaflets that came with the drugs to feel I had actually understood what each was for and why. Like I said, other people just follow the doctors instructions or rely on their partner or carer. Posts.Title: 4 vs 6 TCH

Posts.Content: hi mossom2  I had EC and T with Herceptin and it was a marathon, the 4 x EC started on August 17th 2015, every three weeks and then switched to accelerated T every two weeks but slotting the Herceptin in every 3 weeks around it. The T phase finished Christmas Eve 2015, on schedule and the Herceptin continued until November 2016. My oncologist explained to me, several times, why she had prescribed the regime, she was treating me as stage 3,  and I trusted her to treat me. But she also said that if I felt I couldn't cope she could reduce the doses. She also didn't use the F part of the FEC treatment as she felt it wasn't necessary. A lot of women are still treated with FEC T. Opinions do seem to vary and thinking has changed a bit even in 12 months and some oncologists recommend Perjeta and Herceptin together but I have a feeling that is for neoadjuvant chemotherapy but TCHP seems to be widely used now. Whether an oncologist prefers one type of regime or another seems to be down to where and with whom they studied and qualified, what their current peer group are recommending and what their own personal experiences have been . The chemo effect is cumulative, I asked for my blood reports each time and it did show a steady decline but it never got past the critical point where I had to take a break . So, you are right in thinking that the longer you have to endure the assault on your system the higher the risk but I know a couple of people who reacted most strongly after the first round and then didn't suffer as badly in subsequent rounds. The only real way to decide is to chat to your team, I was lucky in that my onco was kind and patient. Like I said, mine was quite willing to lower the T dose but I decided to stick with it, having got that far it made sense to give it the full works. Which side effects are bothering you most ? There are lots of remedies. hugs Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi Caz90  I don't envy you having to make this decision  what I have said, and I will continue to say, is that chemotherapy carries a risk, I used to say 5% but I have modified that to 3%. So If your team cannot tell you that statistically you are likely to get more than a 3% uplift  over 5 and 10 years, the short and long term side effects and immediate risk of death are simply not worth it.  Chemo isn't pleasant, I'm only just beginning to feel 'normal' at just two years after completing 6 months of EC and T.  I had problems with hair, nails and skin, hands and feet with neuropathy and gastrointestinal problems / loo issues. I've no idea if there are other long term issues yet but I suspect there will be.  AND I sailed through chemo by all accounts.  18 - 31 ( 0 - 100) or bottom third, being the 'grey area' of very little benefit or negligible benefit when compared to risk.  In my experience my oncologist was very forceful in her recommendation, she was in no doubt, and left me in no doubt, that I would definitely benefit from undergoing an intense chemo regime. Others have said their oncologist more or less shrugged and said "it's your decision"   Don't get me wrong, I'm not going to tell you it's a simple decision to make but it's possible that, for you, the risks will outweigh the benefits.  Tell your team that you have decided against putting yourself through chemo and see their reaction.  If they sit back and nod in agreement, there's your answer.  If they sit forwards and attempt to persuade you then they may genuinely feel you should submit. The lines have to be drawn somewhere and I have a feeling they're quite blurred.  I have to accept that I still have a 20% risk of recurrence and spread, despite all the treatments . hope that helps a bit Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi FreyaO it sounds complicated  and I can see why you might have been worried by the consent form this is how I see it, just a personal experience.  I got into the car with my daughter and sons girlfriend and was having a little rant about how nobody was taking the time or trouble to help me deal with stuff whilst I was undergoing chemo and i said "I have cancer" they both said, simultaneously "HAD" as in past tense.  So if this treatment causes existing tumours to grow then it shouldn't affect people like us, should it, we've had all our tumours removed and had mop up chemo and rads and hormone treatments etc. I'm going to tag chloecat45 because I know she has looked into all sorts of treatments and therapies extensively and she may have some information on this.  The only slight concern might be circulating tumour cells and that is something that I worry about but the tests are not readily available.  I've no idea if the people that offer the tests might know if this PEMF treatment causes problems with circulating tumour cells. This is my thinking, I've read that most people have mutated cells but the body flushes them out, it's only when they settle and congregate they cause tumours and cancerous tumours can be a problem. Since we are susceptible as we have had to have our tumours removed I would imagine there may still be a slight risk of circulating tumour cells and a sightly higher likelihood of them settling to form more tumours.  If we have circulating tumour cells in our bodies we don't want to upset them, do we.  Are there other treatments for your poor leg, I'm guessing resting with the leg up isn't an option ? hugs Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: found it ...  this is from our Ask an Expert section :   Richard answering a question about aches and pains ... I'm beginning to see how challenging it can be to reassure people over the internet! It's very difficult without more information and a quick examination would usually be all that is needed to reassure however I hope I can share some reassuring thoughts: It would be exceptionally rare in my experience for breast cancer to affect the knee as a lump - in fact in 19 years of seeing patients with breast cancer I cannot think of a single case! It's hard after a breast cancer diagnosis to ignore "lumps and bumps" or "aches and pains" and they deserve some attention, I have two important questions I ask my patients; "How long has it been there?" (Persistence) and "Is it getting worse?" (Severity). Lumps / pain caused by cancer tend not to improve on their own or get better with time ; problems that are not improving need to be checked out. Problems caused by cancer tend to increase as cancer grows over time - therefore lumps that are getting bigger or pains that are getting worse should be checked out. It is never "worrying for nothing" because thinking about new problems carefully helps you remain aware of what is happening to your body. It would be rare for a knee to be affected but if things get worse or don't get better you should ask to be examined.

Posts.Title: Happiness vs Meaningfulness - an interesting article

Posts.Content: I had gestational diabetes with both my younger children and for the youngest I reduced my refined sugar intake to almost zero. It was very hard as there are a lot of sugars included in things you don't expect, M&S bread for instance. I checked my blood sugars 3 x per day for 9 months.  But he was still nearly 8 lbs, whereas I'd eaten pretty much what I wanted when I'd had my daughter and she was 9lbs.  One of the more experienced midwives said, some women just have bigger babies. It just stuck in my mind, of course I put on hardly any weight myself with my son as I had with my daughter but then I shed the weight instantly with her because she fed really well, where my son didn't ever really feed that well and I had to go back to work really quickly. But overall I don't eat nearly the common average of refined sugar because I'm just not in the habit any more, that's until I developed a bit of a weakness for pain-au-raisin during chemo. I get really seriously fed up with magazine articles that ask whether organic food tastes better.  That's not the point.  Organic is better for you, less chemicals are better for you, better made products are better for you, free range 'happy' meat is better for you.  Grass fed dairy has a better source of K2 which could help prevent build up of calcium in the body, and breasts, which is a known focal point of breast cancer. I KNOW I am allergic to some household cleaners, my face tingles when my husband uses them.  I stopped buying them after my diagnosis only to find that he'd deliberately gone into town to buy the specific ones I'd told him I'd stopped buying in favour of ones I didn't react to. Is he trying to 'finish me off' I wonder ??? I had to swap shampoo because when my hair grew sufficiently and I thought I'll just wash my hair, my scalp itched, burned and tingled with the usual stuff, so I'm using Daniel Galvin Jr  sls free stuff now. I did consider getting a household water filter, chlorine isn't safe to use but it is cheap and better than using untreated water, but it's not good for you. After all is said and done I still have to accept that I got breast cancer and that despite all the treatment it may come back, spread and kill me. The one thing I did try to avoid was stress but with my husband around that is really hard, it took me an hour searching for a small gift for my aunt that he'd moved (tidied up) and usually I don't bother to ask as he just says,  "it can't be far away"  and so starts the hide and seek game. He did tell me he'd put it somewhere but I found it somewhere else.  It's a waste of time and effort, a real frustration but he keeps doing it, he seems to get a kick out of it. I used to wear clips in my hair to keep it out of my eyes and he didn't like it, he preferred me to wear it down, so he'd walk behind me and un-clip it, to begin with it was a joke but one night I wanted to read with the youngest and couldn't find a clip and spent a good half an hour getting properly pissed off searching the house, wasting valuable time that I could have been reading. I walked into the office and shouted at him that it was all too much and it was no longer just about the hair clip. He got up walked out and came back with .. a hair clip .. he won't change Look after yourself as best you can, eat less, move more. Sleep. Eat food that doesn't come in a packet more often than boxed up stuff. If you want to drink, drink with food, your body handles it better and don't drink to get drunk. Enjoy yourself and be happy, surround yourself with people you like or get used to your own company. enjoy sunshine and blue skies because at the end of the day you want to look back and sigh and say I had a good time hugs Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi candytop  it's easier when it's put in terms we can understand, I like pictures, but let me see if i can help the overall figure is 1 in 8, so if there were 32 seats on the top of the bus 4 of them would have breast cancer but that doesn't really tell the whole story, we need a plane load of women if there were 960 women on a plane then 120 would have breast cancer if we look at that group of 120 women with breast cancer, • 80 will be ER+ or PR+ and (staged 1, 2 or 3)   -- chemo represents hardly any benefit to a lot of women in this group, 30 out of the 40, the rest get offered chemo but it will only help half but we don't know which half, 5 will go through chemo unnecessarily. • 24 will be Her2+ (stage 1, 2 or 3)    -- chemo is a good treatment for Her2+ • 12 will have triple negative   -- chemo is a good treatment for TNBC • 2 will have DCIS    -- chemo doesn't affect DCIS • 2 will have either lobular or inflammatory breast cancer --   one will benefit one won't  but we need about 10 women in this group • 2 will have advanced or metastatic breast cancer, one diagnosed at the same time as primary  -- chemo is offered periodically but that's adding up to more than 120 we need more women so that we could further divide this group into those that suffer a recurrence before spread and those that are diagnosed with both primary and secondaries at the same time, women that have DCIS and have a lumpectomy, those who need a mastectomy ... we're gonna need a bigger plane This is theoretical and very simplified.  It's an illustration rather than being absolutely factual. if we had that massive plane, for each 100 women facing the decision on whether to have chemo or not in the ER+/PR+ group the decision to have chemo or not will affect 4 or 5 women. But, like my advertising budget, I know half of it is wasted, trouble is I don't know which half. take two women, both have ER+ breast cancer, tiny tumour, 10mm, grade 1, no lymph involvement, they both stand an excellent chance of being completely cured and there really is no benefit to putting them through chemo, especially when you consider the risks involved. take another two women, both ER+, two tumours, one lymph node involved, grade 3, the stats say that one of these women will benefit but we have no way of knowing which one, there is no test to see who is more receptive to chemo or even which type of chemo. If I have to pick one of the women to have chemo and the other not, I have no guarantee I have picked the right women. We just have to wait and see, and be vigilant. In reality, for most of us it's probably easier to think in terms of 100 women, 90 of them will walk away after successful treatment and put breast cancer firmly behind them. did that help at all ? hugs Carolyn xx NB  that 1 in 8 figure is for all women of all ages, so I think excludes pre-pubescent girls, I can't think of the adjusted figure so let's stick with 1 in 8

Posts.Content: did you have a look at the images ?  I found it helped. I also had my large lump for nearly 3 years.  My first official breast screening in 2012 failed to detect it but when we reviewed the scans next to the ones at my private screening in May 2015 it was clearly there. Screening isn't an exact science, especially the routine ones. I had mammogram and ultrasound, then ultrasound guided biopsies of the area, upper outer left breast,  and the lymph node but both the consultants agreed I'd need an MRI and that then showed up another suspicious area on the upper inner area of the left breast. The combination of the imaging techniques gives a better picture for the team to see what's going on. Even after all that the microscopic examination will reveal what's actually going on. For large areas they seem to prefer mastectomy and there's a variety of reconstruction options, that's another set of info to get your head around.  I couldn't fathom why everyone was all smiles in my report / results meeting but now I can see that it all could have been so much worse.  The consultant was so happy to tell me I 'only' had DCIS and I'd 'only' need a mastectomy. Very weird. the breast care nurse said that I was 'over anxious' ... and to see my GP for some pills.  Lorazepam work as a temp fix. Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi Jojo4  I can see you've been busy on here, it's useful, I didn't find the Online Community until after I finished chemotherapy. The time I needed it most was between the biopsy and the results meeting. I googled everything I could get my hands on but strangely enough DCIS didn't crop up in my searches. I had a 75mm 'suspicious area', it wasn't round, if it had been I'm sure I'd have spotted it sooner, 75mm is a tennis ball ! Anyway, DCIS is the earliest stage, stage 0. https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/38/p/115749/924472#924472 that link is to a nice set of illustrations, my doctors all tried drawing it but this is neater.  It shows how the cancerous cells start to break down and then become invasive. Since DCIS isn't life threatening it's not considered that serious but obviously the more there is of it, or the larger the affected area, the more likely it is to be hiding invasive cells within it.   And that's what happened to me. I had a left mastectomy in July last year, with immediate implant reconstruction, but once the breast tissue was examined under the microscope there was significant areas of invasive cells and I was recommended chemo.  The one lymph node they all thought looked dodgy turned out to be okay. try not to panic too much and just try and keep busy I try and walk most days but I've had to put a bit more effort into the business and the days are shorter, so I've slacked a bit but I start with good intentions. Posts.Content: hi wombat.23  I went to my GP in 2011 and 2012 dozens of times but because I didn't have a 'lump' he dismissed all my symptoms as menopause and hormones. The bit I find most frustrating is that I'd been called in for mammograms for my lumpy breasts on a few occasions but nothing sinister was found. Why wasn't I on a 'double' check list. I had my first routine mammogram in 2012 which was just reported as 'clear'.  Even the operator frowned at my breasts, i just thought, it's okay everyone wants to double check them. Roll on to 2015 and I'd booked a private screening since I wasn't getting any joy on the NHS and there is was, 75mm.  But when biopsied it only revealed DCIS. The consultant and radiologist both agreed it should have been spotted in 2012, it's clearly there on the mammogram.  So that's 3 years at least, that we know about. Other people have a tiny lump, they go to their GP straight away, get an immediate urgent referral and find it's spread. There's no logic to it. I felt stupid for not spotting something that was 75mm but to be fair to me I couldn't have done much more, I'd pestered my GP and had scans. In fact I'd had scans and clinic appointments for all sorts of things, all came back clear. My biggest problem now is trusting the scans, my bone and CAP scans were clear but then all my scans were 'clear'. I've asked for another review in the new year but the Royal Marsden has started to not offer routine scans, in favour of requests, but the requests have to be based on the two criteria persistence and severity, in other words, a specific symptom that is there constantly and is getting progressively worse. I've signed up for that programme which is nurse specialist lead, part of it is helping us move on and get over the constant fear of recurrence and spread. I'll keep you all informed as to its usefulness hugs Carolyn xx

I'm going with patience rather than strength , I'm not going to say 'stay strong', I'm going to say ...  be patient just keep it together for a bit longer because in a while it will all become easier to deal with. Every time I talked about it it made a bit more sense, logically, not emotionally, the emotional roller coaster goes on for a while, but eventually, time allows us to reflect today I felt that maybe I was just about far enough away to look back and not be totally freaked out by everything that has happened to me over the last 12 months today I met the nurse again that found a vein for me when everyone else was on the point of giving up back in August last year for my 2nd chemo, she'd taken a few months out to go traveling, but I was able to thank her for being utterly brilliant at finding veins my daughter still says 'don't die yet mum' and I say I don't intend to be patient you will get control back and people will be relying on you again quicker than you can say 'where's the butter/milk/tea/coffee/bread/socks/shoes/eggs/cereal/ ...?"
Posts.Title: Pre-op nerves

Posts.Content: hi Lizz I wasn't sick at all for which I was pretty grateful but I had dia ... diah... the shits ! from day one and throughout and anything I took to stop it, which was basically DHC which I was taking for the pain, caused the opposite effect, and a few people have said the same, it's a balancing act to get the daily movements sorted.  we don't have sufficient words for pain either and I do sympathise with French et al having to do it in a foreign language I have two pain levels I refer to 1. is child birth, which I coped with reasonably well and 2. is tooth ache which I'm a complete wimp at All my nurses had no children and beautiful teeth.   And it wasn't until I experienced excruciating mobilising pain from an elastic bandage round my chest to stop a leaking artery that I realised I'd not come close to my actual threshold. It felt like I was being stabbed but I checked twice and I definitely wasn't. I couldn't move forwards or backwards, I could barely breathe. I was just about to try and shout for help because I figured I must be dying when I remembered I was supposed to take the bandage off at bedtime and it was nearly bed time. As soon as I undid the clip the pain vanished. Chemo brain is real and it creeps up on you, write everything down. Don't laugh but I took a photo of where I parked my car one day, just in case.  My wig was my salvation and it only cost just over 100 quid, which I thought was quite a lot but now sounds like an absolute bargain. My hair has grown back but seems to have stalled at the moment, which I'm hoping isn't because I dyed it too soon  :0 Apart from one weekend when everything tasted like cork or polystyrene food was fine. Cheese and crackers worked for me, the taste and texture was realistic. I'm not sure about fasting, but living off melon for a few days would probably count according to her 'quack'. That first day she describes is down to the steroids, if gives you a 24 grace period, my husband looked at me curiously and asked how it felt, it didn't feel of anything and I felt fine, but then couldn't get up off the sofa and kept falling asleep, so I got send back to bed. Go for a walk every day. Get some fresh air and make the effort to do something normal. I was unable to go a few times, especially at the end when my toenails were threatening to fall off but I felt much much better when I went out. For the toenails I used savlon cream and a light gauze cover taped in place loosely just to stop them catching. But others may have better advice on that. Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi pipsters  I have lumpy dense breasts and was always being referred for mammograms but nothing sinister was ever found,  it's not wasting anyone's time, it's just making sure nothing gets missed or overlooked.  Breast cancer is easy to treat if it's caught early. Ironically my very first routine mammogram when I was almost 50 missed a 15mm tumour, it was only after many visits to the GP and being told it was just my age and just my hormones I gave up and booked myself a private screening session and there was this huge tumour, 75mm, but it wasn't a lump, it was sort of flat, like a credit card and the only bit you could feel was the edge poking out the side of my breast, it was my arm brushing against it that helped me make that decision to pay for the private mammogram. Talk to your GP and get a referral, you should have a local breast clinic, a one stop shop, where they will do a mammogram, then they'll look with ultrasound to check what the mammogram is showing and IF they see anything slightly suspicious they might do a biopsy. It doesn't take long, maybe an hour, two if you need the biopsy. I was very lucky that in the 3 years my breast cancer apparently hadn't spread, even though 1 lymph node looked suspicious. call the GP for an appointment Monday Carolyn xx
Posts.Title: finding lumps - some advice please

Posts.Content: hi Ruthie I am against chemotherapy for people that are borderline, it's dangerous and carries a significant risk. The risk for ALL chemo for ALL patients is 10%.  That means that 10 people in every 100 will die. Breast cancer is a lot lower because we, as a group, are easier to manage, we take our meds, we turn up for appointments and we check our symptoms and act, by going to A&E, when we're told it's necessary. But I'm going to say it's still around 5% for a 4% uplift.  That's negative by 1%. It is a massive decision to make and I don't envy you one bit.  I didn't have a choice in the end, I was told I was an idiot (or words to that effect) for not consenting to chemo as it represented something like a 30% uplift in stats. Everyone has chemo for Her2+++ breast cancer.   Except those who are too ill or too frail. It's a lot to put you body through. You have to be fit and healthy to even consider it. The long term effects are monumental for some. I got lucky, I wasn't sick, I was never hospitalised due to infections, I didn't have any blot clots, I managed to get through it relatively unscathed but I know I'm in the minority.  There are plenty of women on here who probably shouldn't have consented to chemo, they've been in and out of hospital and are physically wrecked by the treatment. I know that despite going through nearly 6 months of chemo I still have a 20 % chance of recurrence. Even if you are statistically 95% likely to survive 10 years, there's still a 5% chance you won't. I wouldn't. But I know that Kacang is going to jump all over me now and tell you a different story. much love and hugs Carolyn xxxxx

Posts.Title: Feeling so happy

Posts.Content: Hi Annetha  I had that diagnosis last May. My local hospital weren't able to offer much in the way of reconstruction so I was referred to the Royal Marsden in Chelsea. Their preferred plan is immediate reconstruction and I chose implant as I felt it was quite urgent, although they didn't seem to think so, and I didn't want to hang around for a specialist surgeon, and they reassured me I could change my mind at a later date and this left my options open. I have to say the surgery went fine and I healed reasonably well, I had an amount of seroma but it was manageable. The scar wasn't too dramatic and eventually healed fine.  You will need to be patient as your new body takes a bit of getting used to and scars take time to heal. There are quite a few web sites with post mastectomy exercises and it really helps to do them every day, especially for my node scar, I had a bit of cording but had a brilliant physio work her magic on me. If you have an overnight stay don't expect much sleep, they check you every hour or so. Also do keep in mind that around 20% of women are upgraded to invasive once the breast tissue is examined under the microscope. My first consultant warned me gently this could happen and I'm grateful he did, he was very kind, the RMH team were more blasé and it was a bit of a surprise when I got my results and did have to go through chemo, hopefully you'll be fine but it's better to be armed with the information. Good luck x X feel free to ask questions  Carolyn X

Posts.Content: Hi Sally It's frustrating when plans change but unfortunately it does seem common. I felt really ill after my biopsies in May last year, couldn't eat, felt sick and my tumour became darker and visible without X-ray. But I was told I was over anxious and to see my GP for some meds. I was furious. One breast care nurse in particular was quite rude to me. Once my post op pathology was in I was suddenly classed as urgent and whisked round all the staging scans in record breaking time. There is a logical order, generally speaking but lines have to be drawn somewhere and if you're close to one of these magical lines, one doctor might say one thing and one will decide another.  I was scheduled to have mastectomy only but somehow a tumour was missed, we did all the 'should have gone to spec savers ' jokes, that tumour and the area of DCIS was actually quite aggressive Her2+++ so I ended up having chemo to shrink this other tumour.  After that things went to plan as I had no drama at all through chemo. You have another couple of weeks of finger twiddling then things should settle down. Have you had a dental check up ? That should take you mind off things for a few minutes. Carolyn X
Posts.Title: Change of plan

Posts.Content: hi dash123  it's going to take time for you to adjust but eventually you will I couldn't stay angry forever despite all the cock ups in my treatment and part of me is just waiting for the inevitable "oh yes" "sorry" "we should have spotted that"  when I think back to 2011 and 2012 I had every test, I visited the GP 20 times, I was in A&E 3 or 4 times, I got my eye checked out in Moorfields twice. even in 2015 there was no urgency, everyone looked very concerned at the mammograms and ultrasound but it only showed as DCIS in the biopsy results, then you're classed as non urgent again I do still look back and wonder if I should talk to these 'no win no fee' lawyers, get some cash, take a holiday with my long suffering family.  Or at least make those scan reporters sit up and take notice rather than batting their eyelashes at the junior doctors. Having two slides or images to compare is vital, once the 2012 image was next to the 2015 image it was obvious there was something seriously wrong. BUT the biopsy just didn't see it, the consultant was expert enough to say, we only sampled 3 very tiny areas of that 65mm area and there is every chance something more sinister is lurking which will only become apparent after your surgery when your tissue can be put under the microscope properly,  how right he was.  Even the imaging team and specialists at the Royal Marsden wouldn't listen when I repeated what he'd said, they said, oh no, it's nothing to worry about, you're not an urgent case.  Then freaked out once the results came back 3 weeks later.  allow yourself some time to go through the stages of grief, get angry, get sad, have a good cry, have a go at blaming and bargaining but then sit back and take a few deep breaths and focus on the stuff you can do and must do to make the most of your life whatever age we are, whatever stage we are, we have one life and if you try and sulk in the corner those wags in the AWAKE thread will come and drag you out treatment wise, I have no idea but if they have removed all of the suspicious cells from your lung you may find you'll be offered a short course of chemo and then watch and wait, then you might need some counselling or other therapies to adjust it will be up to you to find the right people to help you, I found my physiotherapist was very good, even though she made me cry not because she was twisting my arm, although that did hurt but she kept saying "are you alright" and I'd say "I'm fine" but eventually I'd crumble and she'd say it's okay, just let it out Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi October2017  welcome to the community, sorry you've had to come and find us I did ask this question when I was first diagnosed and eventually one of the nurses did give me some thoughts.  I asked how many people refuse all treatment, the 'do nothing' option.  She said she couldn't tell me due to confidentiality but I persisted, as you do Eventually she told me there was one lady who had chosen to do nothing and she's still alive 13 years later. Obviously she couldn't give me specifics so I don't know if it was TNBC, I suspect probably not but I don't know. It is possible that even TNBC won't be the cause of death for your grandmother, yes it can be aggressive but it could take a few years to progress to the point it actually ends her life and at 90 I'd have thought it could easily be something else.  The treatments are also harsh and at 90 she's much more likely to suffer the more severe side effects of chemotherapy, which can be fatal.  faced with a choice of the sorts of ailments that old age can bring I'm not really sure which I'd choose all we really want is a quiet, dignified passing with no pain but in the meantime lots of parties and adventures, is she a party girl ? hugs Carolyn xxx
Posts.Title: Triple negative breast cancer in elderly

Posts.Content: hi tammj  I'm sorry you find yourself here but welcome, we're a friendly bunch here's a link (opens in a new window) to an illustration showing the progression of breast cells to cancerous cells, I found it very helpful, most of my doctors tried to draw it, some quite well but here it is in full colour. The very earliest stage of breast cancer is stage 0 or DCIS.   DCIS requires surgery but not chemotherapy. If it's that, then everyone will be delighted for you, be prepared to be told the bad news by smiling people, which I found a bit strange. DCIS has three grades and the lowest grade is very slow moving, it can take years to manifest itself as something that needs treatment. How old are you? As we age our bodies and functions tend to slow down. We were collecting top tips for trying to cope with anxious waiting for results phase the other day. Keeping busy seemed to be the consensus.  And chatting on here of course. For the appointment with the surgeon let him tell you what he intends to do and explain the options, make notes, then ask questions. Without getting personal, whether you have a lumpectomy or a mastectomy will depend on the lump to breast ratio, so be prepared for him to go through the pros and cons of each of those surgical options. There will probably be more tests, some will require tracers to be injected into your blood via a cannula, time to get over any fear of needles. Generally speaking the fitter you are the better you'll cope with surgery and walking helps pass the time too. Do you walk or swim or play sport ?? check out the link and come back with some quetsions Carolyn xxx hugs
Posts.Title: awaiting results for a breast core biopsy

Posts.Content: hi Sally  Bee363  my little soap box item the dentist and chemo when we have to go through chemo our immune systems are compromised and soft tissues are more tender / exposed I should really dig back through the archive for one of my better explanations ... In a nutshell, you'll be more liable to pick up infections, that's pretty common knowledge but what a lot of people don't realise is that a super quick way for infections to creep into our blood stream is via the gums. Most people are like, what's flossing got to do with neutropenic sepsis???  Most of the time we cope with the bacterial build up in our mouths perfectly fine but while going through chemo it can cause problems. Book an appointment with your dentist and hygienist and then get some Corsodyl daily and a nice soft toothbrush. I went overboard and got a water flosser, it was fun but I'm sure I didn't really need it. Just floss carefully without impacting the gum line. Sort of a fun thing to worry about, take the mind off the rest of it. Anyway it's Friday. You have to stop worrying for the weekend, you can start up again Monday morning. Carolyn x

I still look very different to how I did but I have eyebrows and lashes and hair, which I can style and I've dyed it back to brown. Posts.Content: back ... now for the ramble why chemo • in advance of surgery to shrink tumours, • where surgery isn't possible, and • after surgery to mop up any stray cells why not chemo • other health factors which might make chemo too risky, age and life stage etc • low to moderate improvement in stats • personal preference, family or work commitments, not all of us can take six months off • chemo effectiveness varies patient to patient and in some cases the risks outweigh the benefits this is very simplistic but sometimes it helps to keep it simple I was told that everyone who has Her2+ breast cancer is offered chemo and that NICE haven't approved Herceptin without it, so if I wanted to survive more than 5 years I was told I'd be an idiot to refuse, I don't think she used the word idiot but she did threaten to look me in the room until I agreed. I have since found out that not everyone who is Her2+ is offered chemo but I'm thinking that's very early stages and tiny tumours with no lymph node involvement . https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28382636 This article supports what we've heard or been told about chemo not being as effective in treating ILC (invasive lobular) or has limited impact on outcomes, whichever phrase your prefer.  *edited. However your team might say that because your tumours were on the large side, over 50mm (65mm in my case) and a few lymph nodes were affected, they may suggest that it could be beneficial but chemo is brutal and the side effects are much more profound and long lasting than they allude to. I might start another thread about this topic actually, but I really struggled after chemo and I had my last dose Christmas Eve 2015. I saw you posted support for someone else, we're all in it together and I found it really helped to have someone to confide in on here.  You're still in shock or rather you're still in the middle of the grieving process. Shock, disbelief, denial, confusion, anger, sadness, blaming & bargaining, acceptance and moving on, and I went round and round rather than being able to move swiftly through it.   Did they give you a contact card, I was given the number for the breast care nurses, all of whom were a bit useless in the two hospitals i had dealings with but I've heard others found theirs helpful and informative and very supportive.  Just so you know, I usually advocate for saying 'no' to chemo because I think some people feel pressured into accepting it and sometimes the risks really do outweigh the benefits.  The overall risk with chemo is 10%, that's a 10% risk of death, all cancers and all patients.  Breast is a lot lower, something like 3% because breast cancer is treatable and mostly curable, we're good patients, we attend our appointments and take our medications.  So unless you are given an improvement of 10% I'd say no thanks. Mine was something 50% improving to 80% using the Predict tool and this is the bit I'm not sure on, I don't know if that tool works for lobular.  https://breast.predict.nhs.uk That's the link, feel free to play with it but I can't see ILC, quiz the oncologist on Monday ! Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: hi Sophie this isn't scientific but I was adamant I didn't want chemo because everyone I knew who'd had chemo had died.  Looking back now they were all pretty sick in any case, people do die as a result of cancer despite huge leaps forward in treatment, both drug types and dosing. People die, that's a fact of life, at some point medical science will be so effective that it will force us to choose how and when we die and I'd seriously not be able to cope with making that decision ! The admins don't like this topic being debated because it worries people BUT it needs saying, I was told it, quite matter of factly. this bit is science, it's freely available  www.cancerresearchuk.org/.../how-cancer-can-spread Cancerous cells that are well defined are not too much of a problem but the less well defined they become the more risk the pose. Once the outer membrane is breached they become infiltrating and they then have the capacity to travel around the body either in the lymphatic system, can be caught in the nodes or the blood stream. This is what happens when cancers metastasise or spread, forming cancers remote from the origin. Breast cancer can spread anywhere but usually goes to bones, lungs, liver and/or brain.  See, it's not a nice topic to have to get a grip on and it's all a bit scary. It's as well to make people aware of possible symptoms, tummy ache, headache, bone pain, breathlessness and dry cough,  because it's still important to discover spread early, despite everyone telling me the outcomes don't vary, that's another debate actually, remind me.  Chemo works to 'mop up' stray cells, it's a systemic treatment, I had to look that up when I was diagnosed and I just had to look it up again now. Surgery cuts out the affected part when possible. There is the potential for some stray cells to escape during surgery and everyone acknowledges this, there is also potential during biopsy, people tend to try and shove that fact under the rug. But logic tells you it's the same, incision and spillage.  The body can deal with some rogue cells but at a point, a tipping point, the body stops dealing with them and they become a problem. I was told that cancer doesn't get better on its own and on the whole that's correct, there's going to be exceptions that prove that rule but mostly once we reach that tipping point we start to feel ill and probably get around to doing something about it, the 'Be Clear on Cancer' campaign urged us to do that, I did but my symptoms weren't classic enough and I wasn't quite old enough at 48 and I was missed.  This bit isn't science ...  it's just what happened to me. I had symptoms for several years, nothing to do with breast cancer, I had an itchy eye that looked like an allergy, it wouldn't clear up, I saw dozens of doctors, most of them couldn't even see the problem . I felt under the weather but not really ill. I'd been through an immensely stressful time and I couldn't afford to take myself off to soak up some sun. I was also going through the menopause and two of my GPs said it was all down to that.  I had dozens of tests, all clear.  With the benefit of hindsight i'd have been a fool to refuse chemo, I think I'd had cancer cells circulating in my body for all that time, thankfully they didn't cluster and settle elsewhere, it was confined to my breast. But post surgery I still didn't heal and I had a UTI, although the 2nd lot of antibiotics worked on it.  You've had something that won't heal up on its own nor with repeated efforts with medication. I'd have thought your team would recognise that as a trigger to push you to go through with chemo, did you mention it when you saw them? Sometimes we don't put 2 and 2 together.  IF you can persuade them to find you a circulating tumour cell test you'll have your answer.  https://www.oncologica.com/precision-oncology/ these people have some interesting stuff, not sure how applicable it is, and I know the NHS does fund some tests. sorry for the ramble, again    and I hope I've helped, I struggled for two whole weeks with my decision, as I said I was adamant I didn't want chemo but my oncologist was not going to take no for an answer . I have suggested that to people, say no and if they lean back in their chair and nod, you're good with a 'no', if they lean forward and grab your wrist tight, as mine did, you'll know you're in for a hot debate for a 'yes'.  Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: evening cat53  let's start with the simple bit and that's the copied text from the Google search for parenchyma , below, which is functional tissue, i.e. the milk ducts etc as opposed to muscles  parenchyma pəˈrɛŋkɪmə/ noun ANATOMY the functional tissue of an organ as distinguished from the connective and supporting tissue. "the liver parenchyma" now the less easy part, how not to worry about more cancer ... I had scans that missed obvious tumours which were never reported but I have seen a couple of instances where other patients simply weren't told.  I know I didn't take in everything that was said to me in appointments and I felt stupid keeping asking the same questions over and over but frankly the whole diagnosis was a head freak.  So it could be that you were told and just didn't hear or they just didn't mention it because it was of 'no importance'. Either way you know about it now and you need answers, otherwise you'll worry.  I have lumpy dense breasts and my right breast has had "dense but unremarkable" as a statement in the report, makes me feel so attractive . For me my right breast is suspicious because it looked exactly the same as the left which had the cancer, the lumpy bits, one of which turned out to be a cancerous tumour in my left breast, the crepey skin, the slightly orange peel effect but apparently the right one is fine. In my humble opinion, and from my own experience, I had a suspicious lump that was missed in my routine mammogram in 2012 but by 2015 it was sort of a little bit more noticeable so I got it checked, at which point they agreed it had been suspicious all along.  Once I'd had it biopsied it freaked out and you could tell that it flared up, and although it only presented as DCIS via the biopsy and was therefore not urgent, I felt really quite ill by the time they got around to surgically removing it six weeks later. Looking into it there is a small but quite well documented group whose cancer reacts badly to being biopsied and I'm guessing it's for that reason they don't routinely go prodding around.  The only thing you can really do is ask your GP to look into it with you and request a more in-depth report on this 'benign mass'. It won't necessarily turn into a cancer but it would be foolish to ignore the possibility.  Most BCNs will tell you that signs and symptoms are really obvious but reading experiences on here i'd say that's just not true.  How did I have breast cancer for 3 whole years and not realise ? How did I miss a 75mm tumour ? How lucky do I feel that it hadn't spread in that time or in the 6 weeks it took them to surgically remove my breast and then discover aggressive Her2+++ in the pathology AND a whole 12mm tumour the surgeon had missed completely.  It is down to us to keep check.  On the up side they know about it and they know it hasn't changed in 3 years. My lump definably changed in that 3 year period.  but I'd still ask questions  Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi Pollydog did you have any further thoughts ? I did get an answer from the Oncofocus people, if you're interested ? >> As you have probably already read, the Oncofocus® test is applicable to all cancers (except lymphoma and leukaemia) and allows us to identify precisely the right targeted therapies/immunotherapies that the patient’s tumour is likely to respond to on the basis of the DNA mutations present in the tumour. This is called personalised medicine or precision oncology. Targeted therapies are new drugs that specifically hit cancer cells and not the normal cells of the body. This means they can be much more effective than chemotherapy and do not have the associated severe toxic side effects such as hair loss, infections, anaemia, gut toxicity and fatigue. Most targeted therapies are taken as an oral pill and therefore do not need hospital based infusions. We have now updated the Oncofocus® Test to enable us to match the unique mutation profile of the tumour covering 505 genes linked to 734 targeted therapies including immunotherapy. Oncofocus® is able to identify additional treatment options in 90% of patients. I have attached a technical overview with more in depth information including a sample report for your reference. << Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi  Rachmeister  bad luck  on the implant I also had left mastectomy with immediate implant reconstruction and the first one was a sorry sight. It was huge and I developed a lot of seroma, the scar look like something had chewed me, possibly that mountain lion we all chuckled about, and it had these tags which I now know are called dog ears. There was also a small gap at one end which never really healed. I thought it would affect the start of chemo but the team didn't seem to think it was a problem. So I wasn't impressed but I didn't have time to kick up a fuss because I'd realised that a 2nd lump that had appeared in my chest/breast whilst waiting for my mastectomy surgery was actually still there, so that sort of took priority over whinging about the state of the boob job. They then decided I needed chemotherapy and so I did 6 months of that first. In April 2016 I had revision surgery and the whole thing looked much better, it healed completely and a lot quicker, within two weeks, plus the scar was neater with no dog ears AND hardly any seroma. I hadn't really had any sort of discussion about whether I wanted reconstruction or not, and it wasn't until I went swimming last summer and the youngest wanted me to teach him to dive that I felt for the first time that this implant was a considerable drag attached to my front. The surgeon wouldn't put a smaller implant in, he only wanted to drop one size from the original but really I could have gone 2 or 3 sizes smaller and possibly even got away with nothing. A mate round the corner wasn't given the option of immediate reconstruction and her original scar was very neat, she's now having an expander, I need to catch up with her to see how that's going. I think I'd give everything a chance to settle down. I'm going to sound like your mother but it's possible you might be over doing things and haven't let your body heal and although some activity helps, you sound like a fidget bottom with plenty of manual labour that requires a lot of effort. Unless you learn to put your feet up and give your body a chance to repair and replenish, any further surgery will carry a similar risk of failure. OK lecture over. option 1 - have another go at skin sparing reconstruction with a smaller implant as suggested option 2 - revision surgery to remove implant and sacrifice skin, leave for 8 weeks and insert expander etc.   or leave options open. option 3 - diep or lat dorsi ?  I can't imagine you opting for either of these but it's worth considering I think I'd ask for the surgeons opinions on whether giving your body a break and then revisiting reconstruction options in a few weeks time will make a difference ? Are you fit and healthy in other respects ? Are you stressed ? Do you eat a good variety of foods to get all the essential vitamins and minerals to help your body repair itself ?  Food is better than supplements. Being active should exclude circulation issues but the nutrients need to be there too, and oxygen. The key thing for me was that around the first surgery I just didn't feel very well and I felt a lot better, fitter and healthier going into the 2nd surgery. With the benefit of hindsight the healing, or lack of, makes sense in that context. hugs Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi Candytop     Oncotype DX is a test that helps determine the benefit of using chemotherapy in addition to hormone therapy for some estrogen receptor-positive (ER-positive) breast cancers. Oncotype DX tests a sample of the tumor (removed during a biopsy or surgery) for a group of 21 genes. that's a copy / paste from Google, basically, if you're having chemo to shrink the tumour they know there's a benefit to be gained, ie to make the tumour smaller and make the surgery less extensive (there must be a word for that?) or reduce the extent of surgery. The Oncotype test is for women who have really small tumours that can easily be removed with clear margins and it's been caught at an early stage. Chemotherapy isn't beneficial for everyone, some people only get a 1 or 2 % uplift in stats, and there's a considerable risk associated with it, much more than 1 or 2 % in most cases. does that help ? Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday Londonlass I really hope you can get the pain / constipation balance right. I found DHC worked for me, but other codeine derivatives didn't.  I was also given morphine sulphate in packs of 50, they worked on my taxane related bone pain quite well.  But again do cause constipation.   For constipation I used stoned fruit, all and any, which you can incorporate into the main diet, just extra for you, tinned peaches is a good standby when fresh stuff isn't available. Do you feed the baby apricots ? If the drug combination you're on isn't working it needs to be addressed, I remember when my mother in law was admitted to hospital she was on about 20 different meds, built up over 10 years or so, some of which were hopelessly out of date. My brother was prescribed a pain killer last year and one of his friends was so alarmed she took them off him, she works with the Samaritans and they'd noticed a clear link between this particular drug and suicidal tendencies ... that's how I remember it, seems surreal now but he was very glum when he was taking them. You can't just withdraw all at once, it needs to be managed quite carefully, and well worth having a good solid conversation with the new team. I am also in favour of minimal doses, which you can work out yourself with pain meds but you'll need guidance on the other meds you're taking. If you were the mum, the team would be working really hard to make sure you were still able to care for your baby. That might be a line of thinking when you next discuss it with the team ?? Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi J jemilyxx  Today it feels really scary but as the days go by it will become less so, KerryCake posted recently that in 8 weeks you'll be dishing out advice to all the newbies on here. Personally I think it was easier to go through treatment myself, in my case mastectomy, and chemo, than have to watch someone else. On the whole I chose to attend meetings, appointments and treatment sessions on my own, but my daughter, 22, helped out by picking me up from the hospital after my surgery, for instance, they won't let you leave on your own. I know she worried about me having surgery, she said so, but I'm glad she told me. She also said some of her friends cried when she told them I had breast cancer, which I was upset about to begin with but they all ask me how I am, now I'm 7 months post treatment and my hair is starting to grow back. She also asked, frequently,  if I was going to die, and I'd smile and say , not yet. We had this little joke going all through chemo then, as I was shuffling around the house dressed in massive fleecy jackets and ugg boots,  she'd say are you dying and I'd say cheerfully, not yet. A few weeks ago I had a shocking cold, I felt really ill, and she said are you dying and I said 'yes' and she said, in mock horror, you're not supposed to say that ... we laughed. If she needs chemo you'll be able to help, it's important to keep on top of infections and checking her temperature is useful. My daughter kept reminding me to check mine. Eating is important too, getting good nutrition when you're too tired to stand up is tricky. She will want you to concentrate on your studies, how far away will you be when term starts again ? by the way, they grade invasive cancer cells 1 2 and 3, 3 being the most severe and hormone receptive cancers are easier to treat too. good luck to you both and fingers crossed for her MRI and results, hopefully she won't need chemo,  the helpline is available until 8pm tonight but not over the weekend, but we check in Saturdays and Sundays, unless the sun comes out  ; ) Carolyn x

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: hi for only a 2.6% uplift I wouldn't put myself through the pain and punishment of chemotherapy, it's not at all pleasant, there are many side effects, your body will be damaged by the extremely harsh chemicals and some of these side effects are permanent. I had no choice, being Her2+++ they pretty much tie you down, they consider you  insane for resisting. Thankfully I didn't get too sick, I didn't suffer neutropenic sepsis and my wig looked reasonably convincing, so I carried on semi normally. But my brain is still mushy, my business partner still resents the time I had to take off, my husband and I have grown apart, he thinks I look like a 'dyke' with my short grey hair, and his distain for my physical appearance has horrified me but I refuse to be depressed by it, I just booked a holiday in Sardinia on my own to get away from him. The children have been brilliant but it's been exceptionally tough on them. My youngest is just starting his exams but hopefully I have been able to rationalise his fears and he's on track but everyone noticed his attitude had changed and he openly admitted it was the chemotherapy, the exhaustion I experienced and the change to my appearance that worried him most. Everyone thinks I'm going to die, maybe not today or next week but sooner than they were expecting. Everyone is treating me differently. They all admit it's the chemotherapy that's the key factor. Strangers stare, small children hide and I didn't even look really ill. If it was my choice there's no way on earth I'd put myself through it. I think a 10% uplift is the minimum I'd consider. x tricky decision x but that's my advice for you x whatever you decide we will all support you x Carolyn

Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: hi Silvercloud, when I was faced with making the decision I was looking for people that had decided against chemo and were happy with the decision they'd made. I personally think that putting yourself through it is the safer option. Everyone is sympathetic and will support you in that it's the right thing to do to prevent recurrence. Not much is said or published about those who chose NOT to put themselves through it. I think the majority view us with suspicion and wait until they can say 'told you so'. But chemo is dangerous and can cause many more problems than it might solve, don't forget this is a mop up 'just in case' type treatment, all of you cancer is gone now. Even if you do put yourself through chemo the cancer can still come back, it doesn't play 'fair'. http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2183545/Angel-Mostar-Sally-Becker-reveals-hero-soldier-saved-life-father-daughter-carrying-shot-masked-gunman.html This article is about Sally Becker and she chose  NOT to have chemo. And she is still happy with that decision. As are a few ladies on here. I called her and spoke with her and she said there was very little benefit so she said she didn't want it, and when she said it out loud her onco agreed with her. He said that since her margins were clear and nothing had spread to her lymph nodes it wasn't really necessary. She was more than happy to trade emails and we had a 30 minute phone conversation. If your other tumour turns out to be Her2+++ the problem of making that decision goes away. But if not, I'd not put my body through it. x

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: apart from nagging about dental hygiene ... which I will still do there's usually a selection of doctors in the oncology department, shop around until you find one you like. I found one I liked but I had to switch all my appointment days around to fit in with her. Do give him another chance as we all have 'off' days. BUT be prepared to talk to your BCN about alternatives. With the NHS options you can be referred pretty much wherever you like, wherever you feel happy, this is not a walk in the park. I had issues with the Royal Marsden but overall there wasn't a day where I felt "please don't make me go there". The nurses were pretty cheerful even though the schedule was filled to bursting point. They made me feel welcome and remembered my name and asked me how I was. Even doctor 'Tazer' smiled eventually. The PICC line made a massive difference as it took away all the stress of finding veins. The first couple of sessions I wasn't that well prepared and had to snack on biscuits but after that I took a selection of fruit and veg with dips from M&S. I did August to Christmas Eve and I'm now pretty much recovered, apart from my Eden Hazard hair style. (Google him) It seemed like an eternity at the beginning but I got through it. sorry for the ramble but I had actually begun to forget what it was like, looking back it wasn't that bad, really, I just slept a lot. take care and let us know how the next appointment goes Carolyn x

Posts.Content: two or three points I'd like to raise  once upon a time I rented a villa in Spain that was 'walking distance to the beach' it took me more than a dozen attempts to reach that beach and when i got there it was like a building site I was not impressed it had required walking up and down, or rather down then back up, a pretty steep hill . but when I got back everyone complimented my trim figure and toned bum, so I know it's possible to get results this way I had read that 6k steps was sufficient to keep everything moving and I don't like running, I prefer to save my knees, and I know I need to do a brisk pace to achieve being slightly out of puff , which is going to maintain my fitness / weight but that if I want to lose weight or improve my overall fitness I need to increase that to 10k and this was based on quite a few articles I'd read on the back of someone here mentioning the 10k and verified with the PT son. nothing to do with marketing or advertising, just a little bit of peer pressure  personally, for me, it's easier to commit to doing it in one go, in sports gear, especially as walking briskly isn't recommended before going into a business meeting but if I'm in London, in heels,  I do try and walk briskly rather than dawdle and the steps will be totted up at the end of the day. Lastly, this headline "forget walking 10k steps"  is click bate.  The article doesn't say 'forget', it says that alternatives may be as beneficial, and easier to accomplish,  for getting out of breath and raising the heart rate.  On the basis, if it's easy we are more likely to stick with it, if it's hard and unachievable we give up.  I advocate walking briskly for as far, as long, or as many steps as you want to, or can manage, and if you can work in a hill or two, so much the better. I'll get off my soap box now ... Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi Frances, I offer my full support to anyone making this decision, whichever route they choose. It does sound like a lumpectomy would have been sufficient for you but for the nodes I'm imagining that if you'd done as I did and refused full clearance they'd have had to go back a couple of times, 5 is a funny number, luckily my 1 node was clear but if it had been affected they'd have pushed for another op and full clearance and I would have probably had to agree, I don't think they will take one at a time. Sometimes their arguments in favour of extensive treatment do sound very short term solutions without even a nod to long term implications, even though the statistics show surgery on its own is pretty effective. I know that for 50% of women in my situation surgery will be sufficient, so for them suffering long term consequences of lymphedema, can't spell that, leukaemia, lymphoma, neuropathy, etc etc etc is wretched BUT since we don't know which of us will be lucky and which will be unlucky it becomes either a risk we have to take or a burden we have to bear.  roll on the day they have a test for that ! Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Great on the dentist ! I was going to try the cold cap but it took so long to get everything signed off, on that first day, we were running out of time and using the cold cap adds an hour to the treatment time. I opted for same day blood test so arrive, give blood, wait 2 hours, then treatment first they give you an anti sickness shot, wait 20 mins, then you have the infusion of drugs, I had EC so first hour was the E or Epirubicin then the 2nd hour was C or Cyclophosphamide, then they flush the lines, about 15 mins. it's a whole day affair ! Half a day if you're local to the unit. I think it's easier to just say my hair is going to fall out, I will be upset, I will cry, but I will wear a nice bobble hat or wig and it will grow back. I tried scarves but since it was getting chilly going into September I found bobble hats perfect. Elasticated turbans seem okay. When I got my husband to give me a #2 all over I tried the wig on and everyone agreed it looked fine, it took a bit of getting used to but it did the job. I'm glad I didn't try and hold on to my hair in the end but my husband wanted me to, and my kids were all for anything that kept me looking like mum and not a cancer patient but they all got used to it. C x

Posts.Content: hi Sarah I think you do need to have a serious discussion with your oncology team about this and show them the Predict score as it really is only offering a 1% uplift over 10 years, they must have a good reason to be offering chemo. Here's mine for comparison. I was very reluctant but I had to accept that the chemotherapy offered me a considerable improvement in my chances, we used two variants on the tumour size as there were two areas of disease, the Predict tool doesn't allow for that yet,  and they wanted to show me the benefits, 50mm is a 'tipping point' and with Her2 + the lymph involvement is considered more sinister too. Here's three screen shots showing the comparison.  Don't forget I was missed in 2012 so had 3 years of progression before I paid to have a private screening as I wasn't happy being fobbed off with "it's your hormones". I don't want to attempt to persuade you one way or the other, but I do think you need to share this with your team. Carolyn x x x

Posts.Content: hi Leonaw123 I had an extra wait inflicted on my because I was being transferred back into the NHS because my suspicious area required an MRI and despite my private guy telling me he'd call me the following Friday he then went completely AWOL I googled everything that weekend and it was all doom and gloom, and the lovely team at Macmillan were actually no help, they just kept reciting the same script to look at the links they were sharing  I was furious with everyone and everything, including myself for not spotting a 65mm lump which was now life threatening.  Then the nurse called me to say that she'd booked me a results meeting in the "Primrose Unit" which is the cancer centre, so I asked what my results were and she said she couldn't tell me over the phone, and I said why would I need an appointment in the Primrose Unit ???  She said sorry and I muttered something like , you will be ... Posts.Title: Advice needed please!!

Posts.Content: hi Sacha I really really didn't want chemo, and like you, I felt that once the cancer had been surgically removed that was it But I had Her2+ breast cancer and I was told that I'd be insane not to have chemo, the oncologist even threatened to lock me in the room if I refused. So I agreed and signed the consents. I'm still here. It didn't hurt that much and when it did I had some good painkillers, the worst pain was bone pain in my left shin. I wasn't sick but that was probably because the sickness meds doing their job. I was incredibly tired but thankfully my family allowed me to sleep. My daughter insisted I check my temperature several times a day and we made sure my exposure to germs was limited. It is a good idea to get a dental checkup and tell them you'll be going through chemo, whatever your dental hygiene ritual is, double it. We have a monthly chemo club in the breast group where you can chat to people like you. please be reassured that they don't do this for fun, as my sons girlfriend said to me when I was wailing like a toddler, they are not doing this to you just to piss you off, they're doing it to save your life. I calmed down after that. nutrition is vital to get you through, especially when your taste senses will be numbed or confused and you don't fancy eating, having said that, steroids make you hungry I'm the worlds biggest wimp but I got through it and you can too. Carolyn xxxxx

Posts.Content: big virtual hug my tumour was missed in my first routine mammogram and when they found it it had grown to 75mm, I felt stupid but to be fair to me it wasn't round, more a thin layer of affected cells, some cancer cells seem to head straight for the nodes whilst others sit happily in the ducts for years, there doesn't seem to be a rationale around it. Posts.Content: hi all just had this exact conversation over in this thread https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/38/p/131880/1026560#1026560 I was citing 'under 5%' but DaisyLou's onco was emphatic that the risk is 3%, so that's what I'm adopting from now on. Until someone changes that, with equal emphasis. so if you have a 3% advantage and a 3% risk, what you actually have is 'evens', ergo no benefit if you have a 2% advantage and a 3% risk you actually have a negative or -1%, or a summary -1% risk therefore chemotherapy offer not just 0% benefit it's actually worse than that it's minus -1% The oncologists shouldn't even be putting it on the table as an option, should they. how can I explain it in even more graphic terms Russian roulette .  involves a revolver with 6 chambers, one of which holds a bullet, the risk is 1 in 6 you'll kill yourself if the revolver has 100 chambers and 3 of them have bullets in would you even contemplate playing the game ????  no because the risk is too great. you guys already have a 95% chance of walking away from the breast cancer roulette table I know it sounds tempting to up the chances to 98% but chemotherapy actually offers no benefit when compared to the risk. I think it is really hard to go against the flow, that's why I advocate for it being okay to say no to chemo. hugs Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi NonnyMouse  it's not silly, welcome to the club no, not all breast cancers need chemo sorry but you will just have to be patient for a little bit longer, it's all about the pathology, what did you have ?  a biopsy or a lumpectomy ? DCIS is early stage breast cancer, or stage 0, and is usually treated with surgery, WLE, which is wide local excision, or mastectomy, if it's a large area, like mine. Then if the pathology is favourable you might be advised to have a bit of radiotherapy which is specifically targeted or if it shows up hormone receptors or Her2 markers or if it has spread to the lymph nodes then you usually will be advised to have chemo. There is a cold cap which helps to avoid hair loss, and it can be quite effective. any more questions just ask, we've all had to get through this fraught first fortnight take a few mins to fill in your profile, if you haven't already done so, it helps us direct you, there's another group for under 50s , for instance higs Carolyn x

Posts.Title: MRI scan after main treatment

Posts.Content: don't feel bad about refusing chemo not all cancers need chemo and even if you have it it's not 100% guaranteed to prevent recurrence in any case it's about weighing risk versus benefits in your situation  risk for all cancers and all chemo and all patients is about 10%, that's 10% risk of death if the uplift in benefit isn't more than that it's simply not worth the risk risk for breast cancer is generally agreed to be about 3% for a variety of reasons if you have other health issues or negative factors it could be higher stats say that for ER+ cancers the results are already in the 90s for most people, some over 95 why would you risk your health and life for a minimal uplift when your stats are already that good ??? my stats were about 50-50 without chemo, improving to about 80 with it, my oncologist wouldn't let me refuse, she considered it madness to even question the stats but still offered no 100% guarantees, with newer findings on stem cells I often think I was unnecessarily pressured  nobody should feel pressured into consenting to chemo regimes  nobody should feel inadequate if they don't submit  nobody should feel guilty if it ultimately turns out to be the wrong decision, chemo is brutal, sometimes essential but not always successful  soap box moment over Carolyn xxxx
