Posts.Content: catchpole I agree.i was lucky enough not to have chemo so I didn't lose my hair but when I was first diagnosed, the thought of losing my hair was the thing that upset me most.I was even accused of being so vain by friends,  I spose because I was in my 60s and single I m not supposed to care how I look, well I do.I grew my hair when I was just over 60, id had short hait for years,but this "older women shouldn't have long hair" wound me up so much,i decided to grow it,and as my brunette locks had bits of grey, I dyed it red,  I love it, I vowed never to cut it short again just have regular trims so thought of losing it uspet me so much, Im sure all these people are well meaning  with this "brave the shave" but I hate it,To be honest im not keen on the other adverts for cancer, I hated the last years one where the bloke sits in an icy wasteland and the caption "cancer is such a lonely thing" comes up.  Totally depressing, Lets have a few more positive adverts and campaigns, Cancer is bad enough we dont need all this downbeat stuff, Hi catchpole, I totally with you on the "60's and single and not supposed to care" I met up with one of my friends mums just recently and she's in her 80's and I'm not being judgemental but she'd lost a front tooth and I just felt, when did you let your standards slip? She was always so well turned out , tall, elegant, beautiful, sophisticated, educated, intelligent, and up to speed on private dentistry for sure. !!! I thought there'd be a time when it didn't matter, at that moment I realised it's not the case, it will always matter. I love the fact you grew your hair and dyed it red.  Reminds me of an aunt who was, and actually still is, the most glamorous woman I've ever met. Also well into her 80's now. I wore a wig throughout chemo and nobody even realised I was ill. It wasn't until I finished and my hair started to grow that I stopped wearing the wig because it was slipping and besides I figured it 'didn't matter' how wrong I was people looked right through me none of the nurses in the MDU recognised me !!  I'd been on first name terms with them throughout my treatment, 5 whole months, and they just didn't realise it was me. Our hair is such a defining part of us.  It really does allow others to recognise us and interact with us. It is a critical part of our being. No wonder we freak out at the thought of it all falling out . And when was it clever to make people cry to get them to donate ?  People are going to die if you don't give us money. Surely it is more witty, clever and amusing to say, a lot more people will survive if you do give us money, without the 'they're gonna die if you don't' undertones. These creative agencies don't give their time for nothing !!!  they're all on BIG BUCKS contracts for this 'easy tears' stuff. make them accountable to us, the 'clients' make them applaud the fact that most people get a lot of essential emotional support via crowd sourced peer to peer routes I'm not saying that it's wrong to shave your head to show support, but as they say, people do that anyway. Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Annie H  I saw the Brave the Shave ad for the first time last night and have no strong thoughts either way, sort of "so what" but I wanted to make sure the Macmillan team were aware of the strong feelings here, in their client group, hence my contributions to this thread. I absolutely agree with the breast comment When I knew I was going to have to have a mastectomy I did attempt to find a surgeon with a good aesthetic record. It was really hard. There was such a lot of horror inspiring images. I'm actually not going to post the full response I was going to because it will frighten the life out of people. However now I have a reasonable reconstruction I'm tempted to show what is possible and allow women to be a bit more proactive in their treatment options once the cancer is treated and they are left to get on with their lives. There are a lot of surgeons out there, some very, very good ones. Let's take an analogy of a wedding dress, I want to have a wedding dress made for me. I go to several meetings with wedding dress makers, I look at their designs and testimonials from previous work I then select the dress maker who I believe will make the best dress for me. I will then go to several measuring and fitting sessions before the dress is made. Once it's made I will go back for any small tweaks necessary. The dressmaker will at all times be committed to making sure I'm completely delighted with my dress. Hands up anyone who had that level of service from their surgeon ? Carolyn x

Never trust a Communications Director who doesn't know how to use an apostrophe ! https://community.macmillan.org.uk/cancer_types/breast-cancer/f/38/t/111000?pi5765=4#1045760 this is a link to some of my comments from last year when this thread started " Michael Dent was the director of mass market fund raising at Macmillan but he's now left, as of March '16, claiming 'Brave the Shave' as one of his initiatives, he's gone to Alzheimers Society according to his LinkedIn profile. " I've never had any response about which agency was involved or what the cost of production or airtime was or currently is, the annual reports show the total spend but not a breakdown. As I said at the time, if it costs £5m to raise £4m questions do need to be asked. The charities are accountable. The consensus seemed to be that the well meaning public would raise money in this way anyway, it's a very popular way of fundraising, if that's the case I don't see why they need to advertise it further ?? There are clever adverts on the television and in digital media, ones that make you stop and think but without relying on the fear factor or campaigns that break the hearts of the very people Macmillan are attempting to help. I personally don't like any cancer adverts, I found it very awkward having to endure them whilst watching anything with my family after my diagnosis and during treatment. The underlying message always seems to be 'people will die if you don't donate' and in those months that person was me. It's frightening and it's unfair to inflict that on us on top of everything else. In that respect Brave the Shave is merely offensive. Anyway, it's probably one of Sir Martin Sorrell's companies and we know what a marvelous chap he is. anyone want his email address ? hugs to all Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: Jess - Admin Hi everyone, We passed this discussion onto our Brave the shave fundraising team and here is their response - Thank you for sharing your thoughts on this forum. We appreciate all feedback as it helps us to grow and to support more people affected by cancer.  Please accept our apologies if the campaign has caused any upset or offence, Brave the Shave was created in order to raise awareness and vital funds for Macmillan and we understand the sensitive nature of the campaign. Brave the Shave started as we found that many Macmillan supporters were choosing to shave their head and fundraise for Macmillan. Originally we launched Shave or Style, however from this campaign, we found that the majority of participants were opting to shave and so moved forward with that aspect specifically. We wanted to provide these supporters with a better platform in order to raise money, while sharing their fundraising activity. The majority of people who take part in Brave the Shave have a close connection to cancer, including the ladies in our TV ad. We do understand that this type of event is not for everyone, which is why we offer a variety of events, including Coffee Morning, Go Sober and Summer Lights. We also of course are continually trying to improve and check our communication with this particular ask, which is why yours and participants feedback here is so important.   Last year this event raised over £4m to support people affected by cancer, which means we can continue to be there for more people affected by cancer than ever before. We hope this response has eased some of your concerns, and please do let us know if you have any further comments or queries, you can email us at bravetheshave@macmillan.org.uk http://www.macmillan.org.uk/about-us/what-we-do/our-annual-report-and-accounts/how-we-raise-and-spend-our-money.html perhaps if you spent a little less than £25.1m on making people aware, Campaigning & Awareness,  they wouldn't have to shave their heads, as part of a campaign we all find offensive, to raise £4m I find pretty much all cancer adverts debatable in their effectiveness and dubious in their tactics. I, for one, would be interested to see how that £25.1m is being spent. I love the online group, I've benefitted and I hope I've helped others.  Work hard to improve what we find useful and ask us to help you come up with ideas to raise awareness that isn't going to reduce our families to tears at unexpected moments in the ad breaks in our favourite TV shows. Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi Luciana1  I only really joined in because I felt strongly that the cancer adverts we see on the television and in digital media don't help us in our mission to take away the fear of a cancer diagnosis, the 'omg I'm going to die' wave of emotion that sweeps over us, the blow that we're here to soften. That and the fact that it is usually fairly easy to check the hows/whys/wherefores of a campaign and with the charities being accountable, you can see the gross spend, although not the breakdown. I didn't see Brave the Shave initially, so I didn't really have a comment but I saw other people commenting here and totally agreed with them that there is nothing particularly brave about shaving your head and I didn't appreciate that my son had felt slightly pressured to comply AND had felt the need to apologise for not offering, that's clearly wrong. I didn't want him to shave his head and I was stunned that he even thought it might be the right thing to do, because of these adverts. The biggest issue I had was nobody recognised me when my hair started to grow back and it's very strange when people you know quite well struggle to identify you or look right through you. Put any one of these people on the spot with a consent form to allow chemotherapy and see just how funny it is, let's see who's brave then !!  Personally I think it's much braver to decline chemotherapy but that's debated on another thread. Generally I think that there are some very clever and creative people in the advertising industry and none of the adverts have come close to demonstrating any level of intelligence in their approach. Any idiot can make people scared, it cheapens the craft by playing on fear. That is just my opinion, it's not Macmillan's. From Macmillan's point of view it raises much needed cash and why would they work harder than they need to? I think they should listen to public opinion and I am surprised to see this campaign running again this year in what appears to be an unchanged format. What annoys me even more than that though is seeing so many people having to self-fund treatment, it appears none of the charities fund raise to pay for treatment and what is the point of continually raising money for research if the fabulous new drugs sit on the shelf out of patients financial reach ? I'll put my soapbox away now the Champ role here is to welcome and guide people to the right place for good quality information and peer support in a time of distress, rather than championing the views on advertising strategies, if that makes sense ? we're volunteers and we're home based, I've only met a handful of Macmillan staff Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: here here I'm glad you have spoken out because you probably have a unique view on the subject My biggest issue was that I found a fabulous wig and wore it throughout chemo, therefore looking pretty much 'normal'. So nobody batted an eyelid and we all got on with things, which is fine, other than I was knackered, and desperately needed support but didn't look like I needed it. Then when chemo was over and my hair was growing back and I felt a lot better, my wig wouldn't stay on my head, so I stopped wearing it. It was the most bizarre and disconcerting experience of my life. The nurses whom I'd been on first name terms with for 6 months looked right through me. A young friend looked petrified when this strange looking women approached him, think online grooming or pedophiles, he hid behind his mother. and so it went on thankfully because I felt I was over the worst I could laugh about it, sort of, but it was a gut wrenching experience. I also avoided cancer adverts as they reduced me and my kids to tears, it was quite horrific to have to answer their inquiring glances. It is NOT big and NOT clever to make us cry to get us to empty our wallets these agencies who charge mega bucks to produce this easy cop out content ought to be made to work harder for their cash let's make it about providing cash to help people who are struggling to look after their families and can't navigate the social security system in light of a cancer diagnosis, they're not going to die but it will take some months for them to get better yes we do need research yes we do need more targeted therapies yes we do need kinder chemotherapy but we also need long term solutions for people who are living with cancer, not dying from it people who need to work and don't need the stigma a stage 4 diagnosis brings adverts that promote inclusion adverts that say we can survive without just paying lip service to the idea we need clever people with clever ideas, real ad men / women not the current crop of scaremongers with their tearjerkers forget the hair, forget the headgear, it's too obvious and too much of an easy option work harder to earn the public's respect not their sympathy hugs to all Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi Geordiebird  sorry that you find yourself here and I'm even more sorry that you've had to experience 0 survival rates. I too can't count any friends or family who've survived it. But. I was advised to have chemo because my Her2+++ breast cancer is very likely to recur and chemo represents a huge benefit in terms of survival to five and ten years. So I did. But I took a lot of convincing and involved my family and they wanted me to do as advised. FrancesW decided against and I have just tagged her using the @ symbol to attract her attention. Hopefully she'll have a bit of time over the weekend to make contact and talk you through her decision making. It will be her own personal account and her own views, Macmillan do not advocate any treatments or refusing treatments, rather supporting you in your decision making, providing a safe group environment to ask questions and debate options. Whatever you decide we are here for you. I could do with a little more information about your diagnosis, 1b is only a small part or it. If they have offered chemo and tamoxifen I'll presume you are PR and or ER+. Have you had surgery? One lump or two? Please do keep in mind that surgery is by far and away the most successful way of treating breast cancer, adjuvant chemotherapy is  belt and braces. The Tamoxifen actually might be the one that for you offers the best chance or remaining cancer free. Your age bracket helps us connect you with other members in broadly similar situations. hugs Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi Kitkat59  I remember being very reluctant to have chemo but in the end I agreed, it was what the experts recommended and my family all said that if the experts recommended it then I ought to go through it. They said they'd be supportive. Trouble was that if I put on my wig and some makeup I didn't look ill, and they didn't treat me as if I was ill. So I got precious little support.  But with Her2, although the stats indicated an almost 30% uplift in my chances of surviving to 5 and 10 years, there really are no guarantees. I'm just about to get my penultimate jab of the 18 monoclonal antibody treatments, herceptin/trastuzumab but read that "if the patient has no recurrence during that time ... "  I always got the impression the team were expecting it to come back and were just watching and waiting. I finished chemo on Christmas Eve 2015. Even now I look nothing like I did before. I was young, optimistic and focused. If I had £1 for every time someone said I didn't look my age I'd be very wealthy. Now I look every day of my 54 years, if not 5 or 10 years older. I weigh a few pounds more and I swear I've shrunk. With my curly grey hair I look the classic granny. My husband cannot hide his disappointment. Not about the fact I am unlucky enough to have cancer but to have apparently turned into his mother. Part of me wishes I had stood my ground and refused chemotherapy, most of the long term survivors I read about had just surgery to remove tumours, I'm still not convinced by any long term statistics regarding chemotherapy. The experts themselves regard 10 years as a huge success. Having said that, my tumour did shrink with the EC. Ergo it must work. Thing is, after they've administered that first dose you may as well carry on. That was my philosophy. My onc said she could have reduced my taxol/paclitaxol by 50% but that if I could tolerate it it would give me the best chance chemo could offer, no point in doing it by half measures. It doesn't last forever. I honestly struggle to remember how I felt, apart from the constipation. If you want one small snippet, which may help, my onc said "nobody uses 'F' anymore"  I had the EC but no F. If you're on the same regime as me, ask for the 4th FEC to be without the F.  Then perhaps go for a reduced dose of T ? T was overall easier for me and went much quicker, being every 2 weeks rather than 3 . My left shin bone hurt and my toes were painful but DHC worked for me, apart from the constipation, but you just need to keep on top of that. Stoned fruit works. And oxazepam for the jitters and to get some rest. There's no point giving up now, as that Mastermind guy says, I've started so I'll finish. Or more amusingly, my dr said I should finished what I started, so today I finished a bottle of red wine, a pack of cheese, a packet of biscuits .... that was doing the rounds on Facebook a while ago, it's reasonably amusing. You're only 57. I'm only 54. I wanted to make 60. I found another stats site today that said I have another 6.3 years.  Actually, I'll take that. I have an aunt who is 93. She wants her telegram from the Queen. We have the same amount of time, me to 60, her to 100. We need to make the most of it. I'm not ready to die just yet. I can't 'undo' the fact i have cancer. I'm on the roller coaster now, I can't get off until it stops, I might as well make the most of it. I'm off to Thailand next week, flying on the Emirates A380 in business class. My treat to myself. I have a lot of living to do and a long bucket list.

Posts.Content: hi LondonLass  which London hospital are you being treated at and where do you stay, I know London can be expensive but have you tried LateRooms? Posts.Content: Google the PALS team at your local hospital and be firm but polite. For me the 'annual' was the wrong date but it was too soon, in my opinion.   I can't remember the run of things now but I was still in 'active' treatment, as far as I was concerned, they'd been checking me and I'd had several ultrasound examinations.  Plus I could see the day when I'd finished the 'active' treatment and no longer being the centre of attention, which is exactly how I feel now, funnily enough. so I had the mammogram and ultrasound and biopsy on May 8th 2015 and I think the team scheduled the 'annual' mammogram for June 2016 but I'd only just had the results of the 2nd surgery, for which I'd had quite  a few ultrasound exams.  It just felt like a waste of time and wouldn't show anything, and it didn't. They then spoke in terms of symptoms, but I didn't have symptoms back in 2012 when we know the tumour was there, certainly none of the classic symptoms, I did feel unwell but nobody said 'let's check for breast cancer' and by Sept 2012 I'd had the routine mammogram and it was 'clear'. Do you have symptoms ? Did you have symptoms before ? I don't think you need to worry, easier said than done, I know but this is a principle and you feel you're being messed around so I think you're well within your rights to ask politely for an appointment that falls into the 12 month bracket. call the helpline first and have a good cry THEN call PALS, you'll have had a dress rehearsal  : ) 0808 808 0000  hugs Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: The great diet debate ! no sooner had I posted that http://www.katherinealbrecht.com/blog/that-email-about-chinese-women-not-getting-breast-cancer-has-it-wrong/  this lady seems almost to have a go at Prof Plant on a personal level, but still makes some fairly valid points I'm the opposite, ronstar, I could have been the poster girl for how not to do it, was always going to end up with something but like I said, breast cancer wasn't on my list. I didn't like food when I was younger, I was the original fussy eater, and I had a mortal fear of stew. School dinners were a nightmare, had the dinner lady stand over me every day until I "cleared my plate" which I never did, just missed out on play time. The only food I liked was roast dinner, so I ate once a week. Although thinking back, I would eat almost anything with mint sauce, she missed a trick on that. And raw veg, my aunt said, if all she'll eat is raw veg give her that, but it didn't happen, I just used to hang around the kitchen and steal them before they were cooked. She only got cross about the peas though, it takes so long to shell enough for a meal. My mum actually said out loud, I hope all your kids are fussy eaters, then you'll realise what you put me through. I think she missed the point, my kids eat anything I put in front of them, they're so grateful when I cook and don't burn it. I didn't give them mashed potato because I don't like it, it was quite funny when they eventually experienced it. As for dairy, don't like cheese, hate yogurt, never drink milk except in tea and coffee. Like butter on toast and cream on cake but keep to a min. It wasn't until I was quite hungry and all there was to eat was rabbit and boiled potatoes that I realised I was missing out. I despair of mums with kids with special diets now, even the fussiest eaters on the planet will eat when they're starving. *nod to peanut allergies but to be fair, peanuts were only a cash crop for the Americans, along with the mass corn planting for cheap calories. Posts.Content: personally I'd put 50p on "maintaining regular hydration" as being absolutely fine will be the standard response. They tell us in the UK, and I'm sure they tell you in France too, that before having bloods taken it is vital to be hydrated . So I work hard to make sure I sip water, at least 500mls, over the hour prior to the test. It helps the nurses find the veins. If nothing else I'm being considerate. Also whilst on chemo being well hydrated helps flush things through and helps prevent blood clots. so we know the importance, we get it I know, however, that I don't drink enough water, or squash or juice or anything really, I manage about 500mls per day, possibly a small orange juice on top of that. I drink wine with dinner and usually a glass of water too. Current thinking is 1.6L https://www.nutrition.org.uk/healthyliving/hydration/healthy-hydration-guide.html The thing I like about this article is, it says it depends on who you are, what you are doing and what the weather is up to. FAB ! At last a common sense approach. Switch it around. Why are they testing your creatinine levels? It is to do with vital organ function, so I'm going to hazard a guess that 'normal' is what they want to test, so 'normal' is how they want your hydration levels to be. There's no point in artificially hydrating yourself, is there ?  or conversely dehydrating yourself. the team can then guide you if you need a bit more or a bit less make sense ? Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: chance1960 Hi Carolyn 28 I am going off the original blog but was wondering what your Her+++ diagnosis is.  I have not seen this before and am intrigued to know what it is. Chance1960 hi chance1960  when I was first diagnosed they could only find DCIS, the earliest stage of breast cancer, effectively stage 0, I'd never even heard of it. So they weren't considering chemo, DCIS doesn't respond to chemo, on the whole. But I had a large area that wasn't possible to give a good aesthetic result with a lumpectomy so mastectomy was the consensus. Post mastectomy I knew there was a risk of finding invasive breast cancer cells within the breast tissue under the microscope, and I would therefore be upgraded / downgraded depending on your viewpoint. The breast tissue is tested for a range of things like how fast the cells are growing and how poorly they are differentiated from normal cells, that gives you your grade, low, medium and high (sometimes 1,2 and 3), and how large the affected area or tumour is and whether it's spread gives you the stage, 0,1,2,3,4.  (sometimes referred to as TNM  link ) They also check for hormone receptors and the human growth hormone, Her2.  (FISH) These results give you your profile, ER positive or negative, PR positive or negative, ER and PR positive, Her2 positive (Her2+++) or negative. Some people are triple positive and some triple negative. ER and PR positive cancers are treated with hormone therapy, Tamoxifen, Anastrozole or Letrozole. Sometimes chemotherapy is recommended, if there's node involvement or multiple tumours, large tumours, but if you have a smallish tumour with no node involvement chemotherapy offers little benefit, 1 or 2% and chemo carries a 10% risk, that's for ALL cancers, ALL patients, much lower for breast cancer because we're easier to manage as a group, we turn up for appointments, we take our medications, we check our temp. and take more precautions against infections. It is for each individual to assess their own risk v benefit , with their specialist teams. Her2+++ are treated with the monoclonal antibody Herceptin or Trastuzumab.  And also , so I'm told, always chemo. no choice. My Her2 score was high +++ and I'm also PR and ER negative. The chemotherapy regime I was put on was for stage 3 cancers, they threw the kitchen sink at me. But I'm still here  yay ! Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hmmmmm that's not what the government wants to hear after all the money they spend on the 5 a day campaign I heard through a very reliable source that the cholesterol link with heart disease was never conclusive either. Yes raised levels are present but it may well be that that is the body's defense mechanism rather than the culprit. Personally I am committed to rectifying the lack of readily available information about the tiny amounts of minerals and trace elements that we know are essential in our diet. I was all soapboxy about sugar but everyone's shouting about that nowadays, although Tesco's  stocking the fake sugar variety of squashes in place of the real sugar is a pain in the bum, I'm allergic to sweeteners and I don't like the kids ingesting too much. Anyway, I know I need to eat potassium and I know bananas are a good source. What I didn't know was that potassium plays a vital role in close motor control, I only found that out because I couldn't pick up a bar of chocolate of a table. It also affects moods. Chemotherapy strips out everything and I watched my blood reports as my levels sank steadily and realised I needed to act. I try and tell everyone to eat a balanced healthy diet but to eat as much variety as possible, but just in small quantities. As my husband helpfully pointed out to one of his colleagues who was juicing and smoothie-ing to help him lose weight but wasn't. When would you eat a banana and an apple and an avocado and a peach in one go. That's a bit simplistic. I think the point I'm trying to make is eat one or two nuts, you don't need a whole pack, I couldn't tolerate nuts and seeds in my mouth during chemo, I kept biting my cheeks and tongue, I was almost in tears but when I put them into porridge it worked better, but you don't put a whole pack into the porridge, just one or two and a sprinkling of seeds.  That then creates storage issues and freshness issues then you have to spend a fortune at Lakeland ... that's my excuse and I'm sticking to it Carolyn x

Posts.Content: afternoon all Jenjen30  firstly go with your instincts I felt generally unwell for a good while, 2011 - 2014 but had had every scan and test done and nothing was found anywhere, my routine mammogram in 2012 was 'clear'. I then had a premonition that I wouldn't see Christmas.  This was in early 2015.  It was so alarming I almost burst into tears but I shook myself and reasoned that I had had every test what could possibly kill me that quickly ????  So I put it out of my mind.  Then I had a sort of weird tugging sensation from my nipple to my armpit, it was barely anything but it was another little bell that was ringing in the back of my mind and when I went looking for a comfortable bra because my breasts were uncomfortable I finally felt 'something' with my left inner arm brushing against my left breast and I booked a private breast screen. Nobody laughed at my 'premonition', everyone took me seriously.  Perhaps because I was paying hard cash ... The radiologist said he was very concerned at what was by then a 75mm suspicious area. They biopsied it and told me I'd need an MRI also, so I'd be as well to go back into the NHS queue.  Screening is not an exact science and you are at the mercy of the technicians and radiologists.  If you are concerned get a second opinion.   I left mine 3 years and am incredibly fortunate that the cancer hadn't spread further in that time. Having said that, it might have, it's just not shown up on any scans, yet.  The routine mammogram in 2012 wasn't the only scan I had a problem with, the MRI from June 2015 was reported by my private radiologist and by the imagining team at the hospital I'd been sent to for treatment and my private guy picked up a 2nd suspicious lesion where the hospital team didn't, which resulted in the surgeon missing, what was by then, a prominent 15mm lump in my chest, it had appeared one morning whilst I was waiting for surgery.  I pointed it out to the surgeon while he was drawing on me but he still didn't cut it out, because they follow the MRI reports and it wasn't on the report.  And I knew he was going to miss it, I was frantically searching for a lipstick pencil to draw a circle around it, I still kick myself for not just taking his pen off him and drawing on myself.  So yes, mistakes happen. Don't be fobbed off because breast cancer isn't painful, my second lump was exquisitely painful.  Don't be fobbed off because of your age either.  Part of the reason I wasn't taken seriously at first was because '50' is the age for suspicious lumps to be taken seriously as breast cancer and I was only 48. Breast cancer strikes at any age, it's just more likely in the over 50s. feel free to ask any questions xx Carolyn

Posts.Content: hi Pootlecav  obviously we are all on high alert for more lumps once we get that original diagnosis it is possible this is a new tumour but it's also possible that a small lesion was missed during your scanning that would have formed part of the original diagnosis if it had been identified which would mean that rather than being an instant recurrence it's simply something that was missed trust me, this is better I know it doesn't sound like it but it is I had an MRI scan as soon as I'd had my breast clinic appointment, I had a large area that looked very suspicious and they did an immediate biopsy of the area and a lymph node. At the same time they said they were sufficiently concerned to recommend an MRI which took place two weeks later. In the meantime my biopsy  'only' revealed DCIS. Because I'd paid a private radiologist for the ultrasound and biopsy he clearly felt obliged to report the MRI but so did the London team who I'd been transferred to. The private guy spotted a second highly suspicious lesion in my upper inner quad left breast but the London team deemed it unremarkable. In between diagnosis and waiting for the mastectomy this other lump popped up one morning and it was painful. The London team, having not reported it, then ignored it in the mastectomy.  If I hadn't been vigilant, and adamant, it could have stayed there for months, only coming to light if it grew more or spread and caused consistent & persistent pain and discomfort. As it was, I had everyone saying it wasn't possible that the surgeons could have missed it, so I had to be very stubborn (unlike me) and insist that I believed this to be the case and I was routed around the rapid diagnostics again. With your DCIS and WLE you are slightly more at risk  of further suspicious areas being missed, DCIS doesn't look suspicious to the surgeons, it looks like healthy tissue, something my 2nd surgeon explained to me. Don't panic but DO ask for a full review of all your imaging, to check that anything unusual wasn't missed in the run up to your surgery and therefore potentially missed. If this is the case it's not so much of an issue, it's a right royal pain in the arse, but it's not as serious as a super aggressive cancer that has built a whole new tumour in record time. Mine was Her2+ and that does have a reputation as being sneaky and aggressive but ER+ not as much. Have I managed to reassure you at all ? ? ? ? ? ? ? Yes talk to the oncologist but it's the imaging reports and scans and the surgeons who are the critical teams now. I was more relieved that they had finally take my concerns seriously, and Her2+ is always recommended chemo.  So I had 6 months of chemo and then went back to scrape away the residue of this second tumour but my further surgery was a lot easier than the first, I healed faster and the result is better. big hugs Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi soveryscared  welcome to the online community we are based in the UK and most of the people will be UK nationals but we do have a global reach, so although most of us will talk about our experiences here in the UK with our NHS you may still find people who can chip in with more local knowledge and experience you need to calm down you'll make yourself ill I say that with confidence because I'm the same, I have had spots and pimples that are totally innocuous but in my head it's metastatic spread. I did have breast cancer and I did have to have a mastectomy and chemotherapy, so I am talking from experience.  I did have a spot on my arm which alerted me that I needed to see someone to get myself checked out, everyone agreed that the spot was absolutely nothing to do with cancer but I did actually have breast cancer, so at least I got myself checked.  There's a lot they don't know about cancer. The one thing that's certain is that only a biopsy will give you a clear picture of the cells and sometimes that procedure has to be repeated ... At 36 it is unlikely it will be breast cancer but there is a small chance it might be. And no, a nurse practitioner probably won't have the skill level and expertise to recognise it, her job is to reassure and if, which I suspect it might, the patch heals over the next few weeks, she will have been right to reassure you.  Try and be patient and wait two weeks, it will seem like an eternity but, as I was told, cancer does not 'get better', it does not 'heal', it tends to get progressively worse or it just fails to heal, it persists .  I had my cancer for 3 whole years, it was missed in a routine mammogram . On the whole, two weeks won't be the life changing difference.  In two weeks, if you need to , book another appointment and , if the professionals are doing their job, they will automatically elevate you to be checked out more thoroughly.  In the UK we have a two week rule but some people do find it hard to be referred, their symptoms are just too vague, and that was me, I had a lot of very vague symptoms and nobody took me seriously and, because I'd had that mammogram , reported as 'clear' , nobody even thought to check for breast cancer. Even though, with hindsight, I'd been referred several times over the years for suspicious lumps and skin texture. I'd even had a biopsy on the exact lump 10 years earlier.  We have a few ladies who post from the US, let me see if I can tag Mirabo who may be able to give you some more helpful local experiences, and I mean more local than the UK chin up Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: okay, well, we're all here for you, some of us have been around a while, others are quite recently diagnosed. there are quite a few cancer variations as you are probably now aware I was initially diagnosed with DCIS or ductal carcinoma in situ, which is the earliest stage, it was not serious and I'd only need a mastectomy, and they smiled when they said it, which was very strange but obviously with hindsight I know why they were happy because it wasn't as serious as they first thought, my tumour was vast at 65mm and we knew it had been there since 2012 , my routine mammogram had missed it however all wasn't plane sailing and after I'd had the mastectomy operation the post op pathology showed Her2+ invasive cancer and I was marched down to the oncology suite I had 5 months of chemo but I first had to have the staging scans, which is an anxious time, thankfully mine were clear, but then my 2012 mastectomy was 'clear', it was a very trying time everything seemed to take forever, a day seemed like a week and a week seemed like a month and I actually did wait over a month for the surgery then a further 3 weeks for the results but then things sped up considerably in the run up to chemo I had a PICC line fitted and once I was set up the chemo went smoothly  We have a monthly chemo club or you can just hang around here asking questions as they occur to you everyone here will keep everything crossed for you while we wait for the CT results  xxxxx Carolyn

My brother said that I allowed people to bully me so that had to stop. I think he recognised it because he used to shout at me to gain control even as young siblings. Men realise they can do that and will do it until we put a stop to it. At its worst I had at least 4 men shouting at me, I even allowed clients to shout at me, which I now find bizarre.  As Helen Mirren said we need to find our voice to be able to tell people to FUCK OFF more. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/helen-mirren-wishes-she-told-people-to-f-off-more_us_5600076ae4b0fde8b0cee0fc At one of my first business meetings with my new business partner he shouted at me, he even wagged his finger, but I told him it was unacceptable behaviour and he hasn't done it since. Posts.Content: hi Kate you're not intruding at all I attended the Royal Marsden one stop clinic or Rapid Diagnostics and Assessment (RDAC) in Chelsea and this is what happens. 1. you sign in 2. you wait, patiently 3. they get you in for a mammogram which involves undressing your top half, if you've not had one before I can elaborate 4. they use ultrasound to compare the images of the breast tissue and exam the axilla which is where the lymph system drains from the breast, if there's a problem with the breast the lymph nodes under the arm can become inflamed, which is why they're checking. 5. the team report their findings. 6. you either wait or they send you home to receive the report at a follow up meeting. The one stop clinics often give you the results there and then, which is great but you need to be prepared, perhaps take a friend, it can take a couple of hours?  They sometimes want to take a sample using a biopsy technique, this involves a local anaesthetic and a small incision and they tape you up after, it can be a bit bruising but responds well to paracetamol. Let me know if that helps and I'll elaborate on a few points if you need me to. Carolyn hugs xxx

Posts.Content: it's tricky isn't it, I didn't tell anyone until I got my results and knew there was something to be concerned about, except my husband, he doesn't miss much. You don't want to worry people when it might be nothing to worry about. I went to all my appointments on my own, I just prefer it that way. Men are a bit useless, or the men in my life are. I took some notes, asked for explanations of the bits I didn't understand and on the whole managed to retain most of the info.  Came home and delivered the news. My eldest said, well you made it sound like it was nothing to worry about, so I didn't worry. Bless him. That's what they told me initially, it's DCIS, it's not life threatening, you just need a mastectomy. But I'd never heard of it, so it was a bit confusing. They were all smiles, but telling me I had cancer, albeit very early stage. Of course that all changed after the op.. but the original consultant had warned me that might be the case. He was very kind actually. So, I had mammogram, ultrasound and biopsies on the day, then about 2 weeks later had an MRI but in reality they knew from that first session they wanted to treat me with a mastectomy. ( I just updated my profile to reflect that) It's a lot to take in, it's all a bit of a shock and I was very sad to think about having my breast removed but the doctors were really reassuring about the cosmetic results that could be achieved, my daughter straight away called it a boob job and one of my nurses didn't like that, she kept saying it's cancer not a boob job. I just felt more comfortable thinking about it how my daughter saw it. the youngest was 13 when I was diagnosed, he's 15 now, he just said will you lose your hair n shit? Angelina Jolie made my life a LOT easier, it made telling my kids easier, they'd all heard of it via her, so I didn't need to go into any long winded explanations. It could be DCIS, it could be an infection, you won't know until they do their tests. But if it is cancer, it's very treatable, in most cases curable. How did you find a lump deep in your arm pit ? Carolyn xxxx

Posts.Content: Katedw32 Carolyn - I like how your kids have taken to the news, they are very matter of fact but very  resilient aren't they, it's quite a difficult age with hormones etc... But how well they've took it & carried on with life as best they  is testament to what a good job you've done bringing them up. I hope they're  very proud of having such a good mum.  I do thinks it's good that big names have made the subject easier to talk about & have made it more known but also that it shows kids it doesn't always end badly so not to jump to worse case scenario. The only thing it doesn't show is the emotional roller coaster & battle in between.  I found the lump while washing my armpit, i thought I felt the soap run over something but when I brushed my finger along the skin didn't feel anything, but when I push my fingers in , that's when I felt it, it feels like a solid hard ball hanging on something, like its in the middle off String (if you get want I mean) it's weird & scary too, I have no idea what to think, do I think it's nothing or do I prepare to hear something I don't want to. I'm glad really it's only in a few days time & I'll at least have an idea if it's benign or not X  well the radiologist seemed to think one of my lymph nodes looked very suspicious but I hadn't noticed anything, well not in my left armpit. I think that's the bit I found hardest after the events, after my surgery and after my chemo, how did I miss it ? To be fair, although my tumour was 75mm it was flat not round, the bit I could sort of feel was the edge of it protruding out the side of my left breast but my breasts have always been lumpy, dense lumpy boobs, that's me. The fact you've found it and acted is really good, even if it's nothing they'll keep an eye on you now and they're taking you seriously. My GP kept telling me it was my age and my hormones and there was nothing to worry about, so I didn't. I even had a mammogram in 2012 which was reported as 'clear'.  I was so incredibly lucky it hadn't spread outside the breast in that time, I still can't quite believe it. The second weekend I waited for my results I went shopping and got hats and scarves, expecting to be told I'd need chemo straight away. That was May 2015. In the end I didn't start chemo until August. if it is cancer it's treatable, and the treatments are getting better all the time and the surgery techniques are improving too, as are reconstruction options, I quite like my fake boob, it's a bit big but it's okay I took it to the beach over the summer and nobody stared at it. thanks for the compliment, I try, but there's plenty of things I know I could do better for them, aim higher, push them to be the best and all that, I'm a bit laid back with them I think you'll still need an MRI, so the biopsy results will only tell part of the story, but we'll keep you company as long as you need us hugs where's my panda

Posts.Content: hi Kate I don't think I'll have my other breast done, not yet anyway. I stopped pestering the GP in the end, I gave up and booked myself a private screening but I'm not sure what I'll do next year. Hopefully I'm in a minority, I don't think anyone else has had quite as much bad luck with screening and scans? if you have implants I don't think they'll do mammograms, it would be really uncomfortable for you. For my first annual mammogram they did the right side and then ultrasound on both. The different imaging techniques show slightly different information, it was my MRI that picked up the extra tumour on the inner upper area of my left breast, it hadn't shown on either the mammogram or the ultrasound, so I realise the benefits. In your case I'd say if they don't offer an MRI I'd request one. The lymph system is one of the body's main defense systems and it does sound like you are fighting something, whether it's breast cancer or not remains to be seen, but if it's not you will still need to find out what it is. Any number of infections can cause lymph nodes to swell up. coughs, colds, flu, mumps, glandular fever, allergies My daughter had a lymph node pop up in her groin just before we went on holiday, which was pretty annoying, but we had a GP look at it and , as they always do, he said come back if it gets any worse, but we were then away for two weeks, being over 16 I couldn't go in with her and didn't get a chance to say, but if it gets worse next week what do we need ??? It could have been any number of things but I don't think we ever discovered what it actually was. It could be the same with your arm pit node but with your other health concerns I'd be doing as many investigations as I had available to make sure I didn't miss anything. I wish my GP had been more vigilant for me and had taken my concerns seriously but at the end of the day, that mammogram said 'clear', you can't keep challenging every report. I do have trust issues now, but they seem to understand that. ... hang on a minute, if you only had the implants a couple of months ago this could easily be a delayed infection that could have triggered the lymph node to swell ... Nesslay   how long did it take for your infection to become a problem ????? Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi Carole,  your onco may be novice at delivery of information but he may be right on the ball as far as chemo regimen are concerned there are some scholarly articles citing that the combination of drugs he's suggesting may be beneficial. It's a bit complex, I can share if you're happy with that type of article ? it's a good idea to have an idea of what you want to achieve, a plan of action, then the nurse can help you work through it Who do you want to treat you, with what and when, how long for and what's the desired outcome/s. I'm thinking pick a few from this list 1. sort out the team you want looking after you, do you prefer onco 1or 2, surgeon A or B, and your preferred BCN,  or another team completely, this may slow things down, see later point on time frames. 2. ask for a second opinion, if you're totally confused get a senior consultant to go through everything in simple terms, this is a complex topic and although we try to get a grip it's going to be a challenge. They must communicate without patronising us but inform without confusing. That's a tall order considering they are experts in a science rather than PR arena, get them to explain precisely what they are hoping to achieve with the two alternative sets of drugs, risks, benefits etc. 3. ask for a full set of notes from the multi disciplinary team meeting, I'm sure we are entitled to this 4. time frames, it sounds to me that things aren't happening as quickly as they could, ask for reassurance on this, sometimes we do have to be patient but if we sit and say nothing we can get overlooked.  The squeaky wheel gets the oil, as they say. 5. how long will the treatment last and will you be cured (does anyone feel they are actually 'cured') or remission or 'controlled' and think in terms of diabetes being controlled by insulin therapy, the way we control many chronic illnesses. or preventing further outbreaks, I'm sure there is a word for this in oncological terms, I know triple neg doesn't have the therapy drugs but perhaps that's what this article I was reading was suggesting. then the nurse can help you formulate your thoughts for a meeting with the preferred onco / surgery  team do call the nurses, they are so kind and helpful  Carolyn x

Posts.Content: Morning Croxley  thanks Lynn I did indeed have my overly large implant replaced I have no idea why they put such a huge one in in the first place, but that wasn't the only thing that went wrong with my surgery. It was massive, well it felt that way to me, and bulked out with over 500mls of seroma it was fairly large but even when the seroma had subsided it was still too wide for all my bras and they had said their aim was to replace like with like as far as they could. first go was July 2015 and although I felt fine at first by the time the wrappers came off two weeks later I was miserable, there was this huge amount of seroma that had blown the breast up like a water filled balloon, the scar looked like an animal had chewed it rather than a nice neat planned operation and it had these weird flaps 'dog ears' at each end, someone said the surgeons need basic sewing lessons and I'm inclined to agree. The scar didn't heal properly and there was eventually a small gap at one end. I was very upset (tearing limbs off medical staff and spitting feathers)   and I mentioned it in passing  ( they heard it four streets away ) I'm joking, I'm a timid, shy and reserved creature The second go is so much better, hardly any seroma, healed well within two weeks, nice neat scar, fits all my usual bikinis   : ) to be absolutely honest with you by end of February it had settled down but I was already scheduled for surgery on March 8th, so I went ahead. That was also to do a cavity / flap shave to remove the residual scar tissue, so less of a decision for me. I think because I was actually healthy the second time my body coped better, hence quicker healing, less seroma etc It's not vanity, it's your sense of self and it's essential for you to be able to move on and put breast cancer firmly behind you big hugs Carolyn xx

That was also to do a cavity / flap shave to remove the residual scar tissue, so less of a decision for me. I think because I was actually healthy the second time my body coped better, hence quicker healing, less seroma etc It's not vanity, it's your sense of self and it's essential for you to be able to move on and put breast cancer firmly behind you big hugs Carolyn xx

Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: brace yourselves, it's a long one, sorry ! Conventional Treatments versus Alternatives   The NHS is never going to be 100%   It is a system that allows the population access to a healthcare program designed to treat millions of people cost effectively and as long as a better percentage have good outcomes it is considered a success. It must also treat every ailment in every patient group.    I received less than excellent care from what is widely regarded as the top hospital in the country.    I was assigned the completely traditional, cut, poison & burn approach but they messed up the diagnosis and then the standard routine went awry.    From this forum I can see plenty of women being told immediate reconstruction isn't appropriate for them.    Since I was originally diagnosed with DCIS, immediate reconstruction was deemed appropriate by the Royal Marsden in Chelsea.    I'd paid for a private screening and both the consultant and radiologist were warning me that since my suspicious area was large, 65mm, and we could see it was actually present in the 2012 mammogram, therefore had been there 3 years , I was probably likely to be one of the 20 % that get regraded/staged post mastectomy . With that in mind I should have been offered delayed reconstruction.    The team at the Marsden disregarded this information.     As it turned out I was re-staged from 0 to 3, being Her2+ and had full EC T chemo with Herceptin, via the staging scans for bone and chest, abdomen and pelvis to check how badly they had missed things.    But at the end of treatment radiotherapy was deemed to be of little benefit, partly due to potential to damage the implant ... Don't all shout at once ...   Into this mix, add that my private team spotted a second separate highly suspicious lesion from the MRI which then popped up early one morning as a clearly visible tumour, no X-ray vision required! And it was also very painful.  I pointed it out to the surgeon during the pre-op measuring and drawing session.  Post op , when the painkillers had worn off and the implant had settled down a bit, I realised the lump was still there.    So I mentioned it, as you do.   Everyone told me I was imagining it, even my sympathetic GP said it was impossible for it to be missed, he said, they'd have had to cut around it.    I had to raise a formal complaint to get attention and then was routed through the system as a new patient    I met with the senior surgeon, who is actually highly regarded, and she was so embarrassed she couldn't even find a way to apologise.    There were errors  What can I say. That if I hadn’t been persistent and confident enough to challenge the well regarded surgeon that lump would still be in my chest hidden by the implant, probably spreading around my body.   I am very grateful to Chloecat because we need people who question the routine.   All change is dependent on the unreasonable woman, I read that somewhere, the reasonable person adapts themselves to the world, the unreasonable insists on adapting the world to themselves, therefore all progress depends on the unreasonable people.     Women die from breast cancer, therefore, we can deduce that the current treatments are not perfect, they are working for the majority most of the time but nearly 1000 women a month still die. Broadly the statistics seem to suggest that more than 80% survive 5 years or more, it says 86%.   https://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/sites/default/files/files/breast-cancer-stats-sheet-february-2015.pdf   But that’s a 14% failure rate.   To improve the situation, something must change.   In the NHS change happens very slowly, my onco told me confidently that “nobody uses F anymore” . But here I can clearly see that actually most oncologists DO still use F , FEC T being the standard treatment.  One lady said her chap said there wasn’t enough evidence to drop F from his regimes.   Everyone saw the apple fall, only Newton asked why?.   Most of the problems are sorted by asking the right questions.   Why do women still die from breast cancer?   I know it isn’t something any of you want to hear about but it is a question, or set of questions, that need to be asked to prevent women dying, or certainly reduce the numbers.   It is possible that the chemotherapy itself is responsible for an amount of those deaths, we know that chemotherapy carries a 10% risk of death, that’s for ALL patients and ALL cancers.  For breast it is considerably less because we’re an easier group to manage but we settled on 3% on another thread, so let’s use that but it will vary person to person and for some the risk associated with chemotherapy will be too high, and then we need alternatives. Some of those alternatives are the things that Chloecat is suggesting "HiFU, Laser, etc"  But unless enough people step forward to offer to trial them, things won't change. I wasn’t brave enough to defy convention but I’m grateful to the people who are.   hugs to all Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa 16 years is a long time, may I ask how old you are? and what treatment you had last time? I'm fine today apart from clients giving me the runaround. I had my last Herceptin jab 4 weeks ago so am waiting to see what happens, I have my last clinic appointment of the year next Friday and have a list of things to ask, odd aches and pains, stuff that I'm sure they'll dismiss.  Trouble is I had several items missed on scans and initially my 75mm tumour didn't present as a lump, more a flat area. My symptoms weren't specific to breast cancer, more a general overall unwellness. They say that no spread or recurrence is symptom free but I've heard of several cases recently that had no symptoms. Trouble is if I have a Her2 recurrence I guess there'll be no choice again, everyone has chemo for Her2+++ ... even though , for me, it's either a yes or no.  What I mean is, I went through 6 months of chemo but I know there is still a significant risk of recurrence and spread, and since I don't really understand statistics completely, for me it's either yes or no, which is 50 -50.  I actually don't feel any more confident having had chemo than I would have if I hadn't. I worry, but I would have worried anyway, would I have worried more or less ? If it comes back I'll still wrestle with my conscience about whether I could have done more to prevent it. make sense ? I suggested this to someone else, try saying to your oncologist that you've decided against it and see what their reaction is. Our faces tell the truth for a split second. hugs Carolyn xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo yes or no?

Posts.Content: hi Lisa we were supposed to be collecting customer opinions on a stir fry sauce but we needed access to a major retailer and they said their customers don't like being disturbed ... hmmmmmmm yes I did work but whilst going through chemo I was a bit useless, I wouldn't have wanted to deal with me as an employee. I had chemo from August 17th 2015 to Christmas Eve.  Thinking I'd be up and running in January, silly me, I don't actually remember much until March when I had revision surgery. I don't like winter at the best of times, I was meant for a sunnier climate. But chemo wiped me out. I suffered with chemo brain and even though I knew it was real and I'd been warned and I thought I'd taken the necessary steps I still made some strange errors. Things that I thought I'd double checked I'd done didn't get done. If you are a teacher or a nurse or in any occupation where you can just sign off sick, do it. But if you're self employed or freelance you have to muddle through. It's not pleasant.  I got lucky with my wig and practiced with my Bobbie Brown eyebrow kit,  so there was no outward signs but I slept a lot. I know I had an easy ride too. my temperature crept alarmingly close to 37.5 at one point so I took off my fleece and bobble hat and ugg boots and waited 5 mins and tested it again, it went down. So no trips to A&E, no clots no pneumonia no nothing. But I'm only just crawling back up to speed now, it took all my attention, all my energy.  I know people struggle with the breast cancer diagnosis whichever variety they have and whatever treatment route. Can you afford to take 18 months off ? What do you do for work? What if you do suffer some of the more severe side effects? Do you have someone to look after you? you don't have to answer all these questions on here, unless you want to but you do need to consider them Carolyn xxx

Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I had one of the best conversations with the matron /BCN about the the choice to do nothing at all i asked the question what are the alternatives, in a similar fashion to yourself firstly she said she couldn't discuss other patients due to confidentiality, I'd asked how Rio Ferdinand's wife had tragically passed away so quickly when they'd been told the stock response of 2 to 5 years  I said I didn't need specifics, I simply wanted a better understanding of the statistics which were affecting my decision to refuse chemo.  Firstly she acknowledged all of us are different  then she said that what kills us more quickly isn't cancer but sepsis so obviously I bang the drum on that topic then i said if the statistics show me what happens if I follow your prescribed route do you have any statistics to tell me what might happen if I choose an alternative treatment regime or if I choose to do nothing  she then says that they do have  a lady under their care who chose to do nothing, although I didn't push for what her version of 'nothing' was but she's still alive 13 years later and unprompted she said we'd consider that a success with all the treatments we offer which I found to be a very sobering statement indeed  Their expectations are actually pretty low and they have no contact with those who fall off the end of the treatment conveyor so they don't have first hand experiences like we do on here  what I can say is that one lady I met at the kadcyla gig was on oral chemo for liver mets for six years and last time I spoke to her she hadn't had to move on to kadcyla yet i know of another lady who was given a year 4 years ago i found myself plodding up 1237 steps to a Buddhist temple the other day, as you do, I wanted to give up and go back every 100 or so steps, mostly because they were so uneven but I kept going and I have to say it was an amazing experience standing on the platform with the gold Buddha  we don't know what we're capable of until someone pushes us Carolyn  xxxxx

Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: hi Amanda someone said to me that I needed to roll with the punches  I had to look it up right now your body is 'ill' and unable to cope, as was mine,  but after surgery my body felt a lot better I endured 6 months of chemo, 4 x EC and 4 x T and the 18 Herceptin  jabs all without incident, I pretty much sailed through it BUT I know how I felt and I did not feel well and after the surgery I definitely felt better.  It's a longer story but for now I think you need to 'roll with the punches' but stay vigilant to what's offered, I can see you have taken note of the dosage.  The variables are; the type of chemo offered, FEC, EC, several types of Taxane, some platinum based chemo's which aren't always offered as a first line but can be and then the dosage and then the frequency ALL of which can make a massive difference but it does take time and patience to see what will work for you. Taxanes can be offered weekly or fortnightly and I think they're even offering a much lowered daily dose now. Mine was accelerated T and that was every two weeks. I was told it was tailored to me but when pressed my onco admitted I was a standard patient and therefore it was the standard treatment. She treated me as if I was stage 3 even though my staging was not exact and she downgraded me for an insurance policy recently, to 2B or 2C, there's some flexibility .  Let's say, for the sake of argument, you agree to an 8 week plan to go for surgery and the CT scans and results, and fingers crossed the lesions in the liver are innocent, and you're still undecided on what is the best course of action, you need to be proactive.  1. What happens if I do as you tell me to do? 2. What happens if I do nothing? 3. What other treatments and investigative procedures are available ? 4. is there anything else we ought to be looking at? and keep repeating this list at each and every appointment  you sound like you're prepared for a debate or two . I'm right behind you   Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: last oncology clinic of 2016 quick grope and lots of light hearted banter, as we do that rule of thumb the good doc said, we need to judge these worries on persistence and severity.  whatever lump, bump, mole, pain, ache, sore, redness, itch, rash,  ... is it still there      is it getting worse /            \                   /              \ no                  yes          yes             no don't worry                     panic                      stay calm and yes, will definitely be mentioning the mole, I did already but they just said to keep an eye on it, following that logic it's still there but it's not changed But I know they're all breast specialists and they narrow their focus as they work their way up. Posts.Content: hi Sarah, I didn't fret about my wig or hair as much as my reconstruction, there was a lot of info to take in but everyone seemed to be happy to explain everything in minute detail, and it was the 'norm' to have immediate reconstruction etc. then suddenly when I mentioned it to one new surgeon he practically accused me of being a vanity case. I was mortified. Now I can look back and laugh but it was a huge thing to deal with at the time.  I wanted to rush back to him and recount every single conversation that I'd had with every other doctor to prove that I wasn't more concerned with my appearance than with my health. Sorry you're having to postpone your trip but it will be something to look forward to when your mood dips, which it will from time to time. Did you see a dentist ? I keep harping on about dental hygiene but it is important, the mouth is the point most things enter our body, the gums are a direct route into the blood stream and sepsis kills quicker than cancer does. As for the wig, try also hot hair and hair raisers based in West London. I didn't think I'd wear a wig but the 2nd one I got made me look so normal I wore it most days when I was going out. http://www.hothair.co.uk/home.php keep us posted x x

Posts.Title: Tiredness and aches.....

Posts.Content: Hi Lizz I was told that chemo for breast cancer makes you gain weight but when I queried that it turned out its the steroids  but the nurse said  there is no need to put on weight if you don't give in to the carb cravings, which did make sense to me. I reacted badly to the biopsy I had and in the 6 weeks I was waiting for my mastectomy I couldn't eat much, I wanted to but just couldn't finish anything, it was quite wasteful. Then I went to get my teeth checked and scrubbed . . . Soap box moment ... Once the chemo started my appetite was fine although I think I was quite lucky. I asked for a print out of my bloods each time and it was quite interesting looking at all the trace elements gradually vanishing. My advice is eat a variety of foods, not large amounts just a decent amount of things to put back all the essential nutrients, you don't need much zinc but you can't live without it, and when my potassium levels dropped I discovered that can be linked to mood swings, all fascinating stuff. I try and walk most days and that really helped, there were a couple of days each time that I couldn't get off the sofa but when o did I felt so much better.  several times I caught myself living on toast but once I was cheerful enough I'd get myself down to M&S for their ready prep' melon and veg salad things they do. I did put on a bit of weight which I'm still trying to shift but nothing too drastic, I still fit in my clothes . Carolyn X

Posts.Content: hi Ann I don't run but I do walk briskly around the local park and I did that every day going through chemo apart from about 3 or 4 days where it was seriously wet or right at the end when my toenails were hanging off. Will you be having EC and then T ?   I had 4 x EC every three weeks and then 4 x accelerated T every two weeks, with Herceptin which was 3 weekly. started 17th August 2015 and finished on schedule Christmas Eve. I checked my temp several times a day and upped my mouth hygiene, your gums are a direct link to your blood stream . Anyway, running, if you don't feel like running a brisk walk will still get your circulation going. Tiredness was incredible, I managed to get up and walk downstairs then fell asleep on the sofa. Chemo brain is real. take notes I didn't take the steroids they gave me and thankfully didn't suffer any infections but they do give you a goody bag of drugs to take home, the anti sickness meds I used one the morning after but didn't need them.  Constipation is a nightmare, keep on top of that. hugs Carolyn x

Posts.Title: How do I tell work?

Posts.Content: there's a class of 'azepams that are kinder to the liver which is good when you're going through chemo LOT Lorazepam, Oxazepam and Temazepam they are metabolised in the gut rather than the liver Since we have free prescriptions the GP or onco team can prescribe small amounts, I had 3 given to me once There's no morning after 'hangover',  so you just get a decent amount of much needed sleep. Lorazepam is also used for daytime calming in situations where they don't want you to jump around in panic, PICC line insertion, for nervous patients in the longer scans that require you to lay still, and some biopsies. Useful in the short term.  I can highly recommend. Carolyn xx

Posts.Title: Clicking joints - tamoxifen.

Posts.Content: hi all Rach12  I had a lot of seroma which was leaking out via the mastectomy scar which hadn't really quite healed at one end, sorry if this is too much detail. I also had some fat necrosis which the surgeon squeezed. For all this fiddling about she gave me a course of heavy duty / industrial strength antibiotics. You will need to get this checked out as it's technically an open wound which will invite infection. Do you have an out of hours GP service, if not I think you are going to have to call up your local A&E and get some advice, they offered to take me to a side room rather than in the general area although in the end I didn't need to go in, my temp dropped and everything settled down. • Did you get given antibiotics when they drained the fluid ? • Have you checked your temp ? • when you say burst, is it the scar that's broken open? The seroma will eventually settle down but you need to act fast to prevent an infection settling in. Macmillan lines aren't open over the weekend but you can call 111 for advice or , if you're feeling up to it, visit a Boots pharmacist. But I really think they will say antibiotics. hugs Carolyn x Make sense ? Kacang ?

Posts.Content: Wendy woo69  One of the other points that occurred to me, rather belatedly, is that everyone else seems to be taking the full set of steroids. I attended the chemo session and was injected with an anti sickness and a steroid. The the chemo infusions. For the goody bag of meds I was given to take home, the instructions was to use as required. I was told it's easier to keep on top of nausea and sickness rather than try and 'cure' it with the tablets BUT if I didn't feel sick or nauseous it was okay to not take them, likewise the steroids. So I didn't take them. And I slept, a lot. The main reason they give you steroids is to combat this disabling tiredness but if you're able to sleep, I'd opt to sleep it off. Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi cehfin  if you look under the panda there's some clickable links, one is for people who prefer to say no to chemo. have a read and see if that helps I do think that we apply too much pressure to people to 'throw everything at it' and then inflict guilt if they don't. We feel guilty enough as it is.  We don't need the extra guilt of turning down what might be a life saving treatment. But chemotherapy is dangerous and carries significant risks of long term side effects, and we simply don't know whose cancer will respond and whose won't. We also have no idea who will react badly or who will be affected more seriously by the side effects. Are there other factors affecting the decision?  did you have just the one lump? in my humble opinion if it's more than one affected area I probably would go for chemo. Carolyn xx

Posts.Title: I've done it - booked flight

Posts.Content: what happens to us when we turn 50 ????? I know BC isn't limited to 50 year old women but it does seem rather a coincidence that so many of us fall victim around this age. I'm 54 now but was 48 in 2010 when all this started. I pestered my GP, in fact I couldn't have annoyed them more if I'd tried. But the symptoms weren't that specific, I didn't have a classic lump, just lumpy and since the boobs had always been lumpy nothing had changed. Then the 2012 screening came back 'clear'. It didn't occur to me to question it, but I should have. I'm an advocate of immediate reporting now. Like how our echocardiograms are done. I said to the nice young man who has seen me twice now, if I walked in slightly out of breath, not too cheerful and you scanned me and found nothing wrong, you'd look a little harder because you've seen me as a person, and I look like I'm suffering a bit. Whereas I just walked in here upright and breathing normally, I joked with you about your tan, you can see I'm fit and healthy, you'd be really surprised to see something amiss with my heart. When I went for my 2012 screening the technician pursed her lips and although she didn't say it out loud, she was thinking, this ones going to get a recall. Posts.Content: RIGHT this is what my GP told me so , it's cancer, breast cancer is treatable you'll feel rubbish for 6 months but you'll get over it, 90% of women diagnosed survive breast cancer to 10 years, it's one of the most treatable and curable cancers. Stats only go to 10 years, sorry. CURABLE, yes, that's right, curable. most women are cured. Even if they tell you it's a large area of DCIS in the results meeting, there's every chance you will find that there is invasive cells lurking in that large area, that's what happened to me. Large areas of DCIS are treated with mastectomy, with or without reconstruction. Then you have to wait until the lab sends the results.   Here is an idiots guide to breast cancer, with credits more waiting and more thumb twiddling, I didn't involve my family in this bit, just breezed through with a cheery "it's all fine" I had to have staging scans before chemo and that is a stressful situation. You will try and weigh up how good you've been in life and how many people you were mean to.  It's a guilt thing.  Let's do the grieving process again, shock, denial, sadness, despair (I always forget that one) blaming, bargaining, resolution and acceptance.  Is that right ?  I always seem to get it wrong but it's not linear, it goes round and round and round and up and down, hence the roller coaster analogy.   More  "it's all fine" Then chemo, and it's clearly not fine any more.  The hair is the big deal. And you are absolutely cream crackered. I slept, a lot. But, you're not going to die.  Not yet anyway.  I have an ongoing joke with my daughter, she says in mock horror, are you going to die, and I cheerfully say, not yet. And I don't intend to die just yet. There's plenty of treatments left, I only just completed the first round. My cousin said after her 10mm tumour was removed, a very good friend who is a surgeon said I'd be fine, and I believed him. For her it's that simple. Likewise for my son, I said it was okay and he believed me. Jojo, you're going to be fine and Worried, you are going to be fine too. but there is a bit of feeling a bit shite to get through first, next summer we'll be celebrating hugs xxx

Posts.Content: hi Ares I had my first ever routine screening in 2012, I'd had scans because my breast were lumpy and dense but nothing sinister was ever detected but on the one occasion I'd paid for a private screening the consultant told me I would need an ultrasound as well because my breast tissue was too dense for the mammogram to show anything but when I got the 'clear' result in 2012 I stupidly didn't think to request a backup ultrasound.  I felt unwell from around 2010 / 11 / 12 with a wide variety of symptoms, none of which pointed to breast cancer and I had every test going, all of which were clear, including that routine mammogram. The Marsden also reported the MRI as they were taking over my treatment.  Private guy picked up a 2nd lesion but the Marsden missed it and whilst I was waiting for surgery it actually popped up as a lump, it was painful and obvious, no need for x-rays to see it. I called the unit and insisted the BCN makes notes but we agreed that since i was already booked for a mastectomy nothing was really going to change.  I pointed it out to the surgeon on the morning of the surgery but he followed the erroneous MRI report and concentrated on removing the large area of DCIS in the upper outer quadrant and avoided the upper inner altogether  and missed the tumour completely Thankfully I spotted the mistake but I had to make a formal complaint because nobody believed me. Posts.Content: hi sazmoz  welcome to the online community typically you will be called into the breast screening programme on a two week referral but that can vary if your area is a bit busy, then it really does depend on what they see at each step. The one stop breast clinics that are fairly common now can do mammograms, ultrasounds and biopsies in one session of about 3 hours, obviously if they don't see anything suspicious on the mammogram or ultrasound they don't do the biopsies but if they see even the smallest lump they will biopsy it. They may also biopsy a lymph node in the arm pit too. The results of that biopsy take about a week to 10 days but can take longer and if they are concerned they will book you for an MRI or other scans which also take about 2 weeks to arrange and another two weeks for results. A good clinic in a not too busy phase can turn you round from initial test to proper thorough diagnosis in about 3 weeks but if they are unsure at each step it can take 6 weeks or longer. For me I requested a scan in March but didn't get an appointment until May 8th 2015, I had my biopsy results by 19th and first surgery consultation by 1st June. I had a few lumps biopsied over the years, before my actual diagnosis, so they might decide it's nothing to worry about at the moment. How old are you ?  I found everyone's attitude shifted the moment I turned 50. hugs Carolyn xxx
