Posts.Content: hi Dragonfly46 There does appear to be some conflicting information here, doesn't there Have they told you that you are curable or incurable but treatable ????? I have a feeling that technically the incurable diagnosis comes when the breast cancer has spread outside the breast and in this instance I'm not sure it actually has, if they can operate and remove the skin, I had a skin sparing mastectomy, then the cancer will be removed and I'm not sure I'd have even waited to see if I could achieve any shrinkage, if I'm honest.  If you're trying to preserve the breast then attempt to shrink the tumour but if you're going to remove it anyway, why wait ? IF however they consider you to be a secondary or advanced or metastatic case why operate at all?  I know some hospitals or surgeons won't operate in cases like this but I'm not a surgeon or doctor so I don't really know all the ins and outs and why's. If you're still aiming for a cure then time is going to be important and the sooner you get the surgeon to operate the better, I'd have thought.  I'm thinking PALs will be your best bet.  Which hospital are you under? The PALs team should be signed around the hospital or you can call or email.  Write down your concerns and questions and request a review.  when you say in the chest wall is it still the breast tissue, not the bone or cartilage ? Could you ask your GP to help you find out via the reports what they are currently aiming for?  My GP was actually pretty helpful in a couple of situations for me.  The purpose of the multidisciplinary team is that they all agree on the best course of action for you and that doesn't sound like it's happening. Ask PALs for the multidisciplinary team report as it stands currently and also a review of your situation in light of the possible slight difference of opinion and once you have those two sit down with your GP or come back here and we can see if we can help how does that sound ? hugs Carolyn xxxx
Posts.Title: Conflicting advice from my oncologist and my consultant.

Posts.Content: hi Dragonfly46 I can see why you might be reluctant to engage with PALs, my brother said never complain about the food in a restaurant until after you've finished eating but sometimes that's unavoidable  In my experience I got much better treatment after I got PALs involved but they were very focused on what I would consider a successful outcome, at that point, for me, staying alive was pretty much the focus, a surgeon had missed a clearly visible tumour and I wanted it removing. The surgeon left the hospital, I don't know whether he was pushed or just moved on. These are professional people who do focus on making sure that if something isn't quite right it is put right ASAP.  I was pleasantly surprised at the improvement in care, even if they were cursing me in the staff room.  I got a better surgeon to perform the revision surgery and as much time with my oncologist as I needed and , as you can imagine , I was incredibly nervous at that point, with horror stories of wrong drugs and wrong dosages playing on my mind.  I also got fast tracked for counselling sessions.  I eventually got an apology and a promise that the imaging team would tighten up reporting, although I've never gone back to check any of that was implemented.  Could you simply ask each of the two consultants to review you again in the MDT meeting and give you a concise update ? You are allowed to be worried and you are allowed to ask for explanations to allay your fears. We're not experts, this is all new to us and I think they forget that, and some patients just aren't interested in the why's and wherefores they just want to get their treatment done and get on with their lives, it's a fine line to tread when sharing information, especially when they are time pressed.  And they see hundreds of patients each week and I know they don't necessarily read up on your notes each and every time. It is a stressful time and hard to stay on top of everything that's happening and you can legitimately ask for clarification, as I did on more than one occasion. I found that although I was prepared to be a patient patient I was often kept waiting for hours on end for a jab that took literally 3 minutes. Sitting somewhere where I was visible in the waiting room and making eye contact each time they called someone in really helped speed it up.  If the current regime isn't shrinking it I'd have thought switching to a different set of drugs or even a different brand should happen perhaps a bit quicker and it won't hurt to just ask that question.  I had to keep on top of my treatment but I really do think, or rather I really do hope, that I was an exception ! more hugs Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: hi Claire ClaireLouB  I was told I 'only' had DCIS and 'only' needed a mastectomy, which was pretty shocking and very weird because everyone was really happy for me, I could not understand why they were all smiling, it was the freakiest thing and a total head ... I had heard about the various steps to grief and then went and found an article on grieving, Kubler -Ross outlined this quite a few years ago and she seems to have been the first but it is about dying rather than other types,  it sort of made sense, certainly after my initial mastectomy diagnosis & treatment plan, I really was grieving for my lost boobs, until I realised they were trying to kill me. what you just listed are definitely the first stages of that grieving process http://www.ekrfoundation.org/five-stages-of-grief/ it might help to read it but it might also help if you lock yourself in a soundproof room and have a good cry I wanted to run away Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi Fi LittleWren  the only thing I'll add is that different scanning techniques measure in slightly different ways. During a mammogram your breast is squeezed, during ultrasound you're usually flat on your back and during an MRI you're face down. Some measurements are in a 3D space and some 2 dimensional. All my imaging reports varied slightly, which isn't an issue if you're having a mastectomy but if you're trying to target a specific lump during surgery then it becomes more critical. keep asking the questions and don't forget you can call the nurses for a chat about this sort of stuff. Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi Dawson26 welcome to the online community  this is the most annoying habit of the NHS, sending out these blasted letters with zero explanation . I had my breast care nurse call me and tell me that I had an appointment with the consultant/ surgeon in the Primrose unit, our local cancer unit, so I asked what the results were, she said I can't tell you over the phone I said well why would I need an appointment in the Primrose Unit if it's not cancer ??????????? She said "I'm sorry" I muttered under my breath  " you will be" she then called me back to tell me she'd managed to rearrange the appointment for out patients a day earlier  ... I didn't know whether to laugh or cry In the end they told me it was DCIS, which is the least severe of all breast cancer, it needs to be watched but it's not 'life threatening'. They told me it was 'only' DCIS and I'd 'only' need a mastectomy and it wasn't urgent.   It's all fine and dandy for them to say that, isn't it .  Now, four years down the line, I can see their point of view but not that week. I wanted to seriously hurt someone for being so disorganised and flippant.  Having said all that, how do you break the bad news that it might be breast cancer?  I didn't appreciate Angelina Jolie going public with her double mastectomy but it really did help me break the news to my kids.  I just googled him and he does sound very well trained, if your mother does require treatment it looks like she's in good hands Carolyn xxxxx

Posts.Content: hi I'm going to try and calm you down ... My experience is that it's worse if you have to pester the doctors for an appointment rather than being discovered via a routine screening. So that puts you in a good position. If my 12mm suspicious area had actually been picked up in 2012 it would have been treated with a lumpectomy and possibly radiotherapy but since it wasn't... up until I noticed a lump had changed in early 2015 By which time it had happily grown into a 75mm suspicious area, it only actually showed as DCIS on biopsy but everyone was reluctant to believe that , and rightly so , as after the mastectomy the pathology report showed multiple areas of invasive disease, of the nasty aggressive Her2 +++ variety. Thankfully it hadn't spread to my lymph nodes or further but that is something I'm still struggling with, especially since it was all missed back in 2012. I also had to wait 7 weeks for surgery from the biopsy date,  and 3 weeks for results. The first weekend I wasn't worried at all but then they called to say they'd made an appointment in the local cancer centre to give me my results , I went nuts, I googled everything and although I stuck to Macmillan , Cancer Research and other trusted sites I couldn't see a way out, the best I got was I'd a 50 50 chance IF it was still stage 3 but there was a distinct possibility it had spread to stage 4 AND I'd had a persistent cough for some months,  I felt I was doomed.  I could see that they might recommend chemo first and surgery after so I went out and got myself a hat and some scarves. I didn't use the scarves in the end I found a wig I liked. You could be unlucky and find that some cancer has sneaked out, BUT I think this is pretty unlikely ... even if you DO find you need further treatment don't panic, we're here.

Posts.Content: hi Dawson26 frankly I'd have rather gone to all my appointments alone but I know some people like company The thing is there are so many different types of breast cancer and they even call you in to tell you it's not, it really does depend what it is. It could be something other than breast cancer that they need to keep an eye on or it could be, like me, DCIS.  DCIS is incredibly common, I only found out my cousin had it after I'd emailed her to tell her my news.  She sounded incredibly calm about it all, her surgeon sounded amazing, very kind and very reassuring and I have a feeling this Mr Massannat might be super nice. Some surgeons are not great at hand holding. The more sinister and more aggressive cancers tend to affect the younger women although that's not always the case, but generally speaking as we age our cell divisions slow down and things don't tend to be as troublesome. Ageing isn't fun what with knee joints and failing eyesight and I'd have more than settled for a few hot flushes rather than chemo, but I got through it.  I think yes, they would call her in if it was urgent, as it turned out I had had DCIS for 3 years before it was reported, it was missed in the previous mammogram . Then there's a whole array of early stage 1 breast cancers, there's also grading from 1-3.  She'll need to make notes or arrange for the report to be sent to her so you can help her get a grip on it, I had my reports send to both myself and my GP and the GP was actually pretty useful to chat through it.  Breast cancer is bad news, as is any cancer, there's no getting away from it, and the cancer ads don't help, playing on people's fears to extract cash.  I like the BUPA ad, reclaiming the dance floor, that's my favourite.  But, as my GP told me, I am a large ship, with a very small hole and all my pumps are still working. I'm not sinking yet. Breast cancer treatments have progressed rapidly and the statistics are really pretty good for most of us, something like 95% are cured.  I also have a link under my signature about women who have survived as that was a big epiphany for me, I was on the tube in London and a lady was asking me where I was going, and I said to the Marsden and that's the cancer hospital so she said, breast cancer? and I said, yes, and she looked into the middle distance and said  "I had that once" it was the proof I needed that some women get through it and really do put it behind them. more hugs Carolyn xxx

Posts.Title: Chemo's finished !!

Posts.Content: hi Lulu8  this sounds quite a bit like my experience I'd had a routine mammogram in 2012 which was just reported as 'clear'  but by early 2015 I had several odd sensations, like a pulling sensation from my nipple to my armpit. so yes absolutely make a nuisance of yourself you will need a mammogram and follow up ultrasound and possibly a biopsy and please remember to ask how they might identify Paget's as mine was only reported post mastectomy http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/breast-cancer/stages-types-grades/types/pagets-disease-breast They bang on about early detection so this is totally unacceptable, I did pay for a private exam but you shouldn't have to . Despite my tumour going undetected for 3 whole years I was only diagnosed with DCIS to begin with, which is the earliest stage and very very treatable, mostly completely curable with surgery. The private consultant was very good at this point as although it was very good news he did warn me that I had a large affected area and they only took 3 tiny samples there was every chance the news might worsen after surgery and it did.  They found enough areas of invasive breast cancer to justify offering chemotherapy and it was Her2+ so they emphatically recommended I have it.  I had EC and T from August 2015 to Christmas Eve.  The other myth the medical professionals cling to is that breast cancer doesn't hurt, I can tell you that mine did.  But I'm still here  yay !! Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi Nicky first go was way too big, it didn't fit in any of my bras and my scar was a bit 'dog eared' or was it 'dog tag' I can't remember, someone will correct me, it's where the end of the scar is left poking out a bit, seamstresses will be saying that this is wholly avoidable and the surgeons need basic sewing lessons, and my 2nd surgeon made a better job, he put a smaller implant in as well. So now I'm pretty happy, I've been to the beach a few times in a bikini and wasn't self conscious at all. it's still bigger than my other one, which they've offered to 'fix' by putting an implant in the right hand side but I'm alright for now, probably in a few months, maybe, but you can't see under clothes, in fact they look pretty even when I'm dressed. The other thing I think the 2nd surgeon fixed was that the stitching holding the matrix in was a bit sore and puckered, it certainly doesn't hurt and the 'dip' they said was easy to fix has gone, so he must have done it. Hindsight moment !  I remember thinking it was so awful when I first looked at it but then had to go through chemo before anything could be put right and actually by the time I was about to have the revision surgery the whole breast and implant had settled down. So be prepared to be patient. I had a large amount of seroma too which made it look like an over inflated water filled balloon, that does settle down eventually. After the revision in March I healed quickly with no further problems at all. I'm not sure what to do about the nipple yet, I had Paget's so just as well I opted to sacrifice it. I'm giving the implant a bit of a squeeze now so I can tell you how it feels but actually I don't notice it most of the time. That Bra Foundation site is good isn't it. Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi Ewansmam a 19mm stage 1 tumour is very, very treatable and radiotherapy is very, very carefully targeted these days, as is chemotherapy although it sounds like your mother won't need that. Cancer cancer cancer cancer cancer there now say it out loud with your mothers age and tumour size the data suggests that 90 % of women are completely cured, yes ... CURED the cancer adverts are misleading, we think when we hear the word cancer it's a death sentence, it's not it can be but that's usually things aren't picked up early, 19mm is a pretty small tumour, mine was 75mm and I had another that was 15mm, but mine was missed in 2012 so it had a while to grow unchecked but it was removed last year and I had 6 months of chemo and now I'm cancer free. I worry about stuff, aches and pains and worry that it will come back but mostly I just get on with thing, I post on here because the people on here are helpful and it was great to find people that knew what I was going through. So I take a few minutes and see if anyone needs a virtual hug or some kind words, or just occasionally a kick up the bum, like the lady yesterday who was comfort eating but didn't want to put on weight, I'm going to check in a minute to see if my brand of motivation worked or not, she's probably cross with me but I only told her to go out for a nice walk in the sunshine. I really think your mum will be absolutely fine, it will be tiring and she'll need your practical help, so chin up and brave face on Carolyn x x x

Posts.Title: Anyone had mammogram recall due to technical glitch

Posts.Content: hi PurpleJan welcome to the community tricky isn't it Most surgeons are reluctant to remove healthy breasts and I can see why. What I didn't understand so well was the offer to 'even me up' with surgery to my healthy right side, which they seem happy to do. I requested several ultrasound examinations of my healthy right breast and they seem more than happy to oblige and I do find it reassuring. Especially as the radiologists don't mind chatting to you whilst they are looking and reporting as they go. We had a bit of a mix up over lefts and rights and it caused a bit of confusion, I had a 2nd tumour in the right side of my left breast but a nurse told me it was in my right breast, so we had a bit of a chat about an elective mastectomy to the healthy side, which baffled me because obviously I wasn't electing, I was acting on information given. The upshot was that we'd deal with things one step at a time. At the moment I'm cancer free but having just had my last Herceptin jab I need to check with the team to see what happens next.  I have my final review of the year in mid December and I know I need an echocardiogram. After that I think I'll just make sure I get regular checks, I'm not unhappy with my right breast v the perky new left one, in clothes it doesn't show, nor in a bikini on the beach. The more time goes by the easier it gets to just accept what will be.  I'd rather cancer came back in my right breast than somewhere else in my body but I realise I don't get that much choice. My surgeon said he's happy to discuss it with me when I'm ready and for now it's not bothering me. Mind you I had a wicked chest infection which I deduced was lung mets, so the breast is relatively harmless. Don't rush into anything is my best reasoning, surgery carries risks and there's plenty of people on here will tell you how awful post surgery infections are. Carolyn xxx
Posts.Title: Removing a healthy breast vs the risk of recurrence

Posts.Content: I had the nurse radiographer purse her lips at me when I went for my first routine mammogram in 2012 but the result came back as 'clear' nothing else just that When I think back now I can't believe she didn't stick a 'alarm bell' sticker on my file, I'm sure she wanted to Roll on to 2015 and there it was, clearly visible, the private radiologist put the 2012 scans next to the 2015 ones, it was really obvious. Like you I looked to see if I could find anyone who might give me some other explanation but nobody could, Macmillan just said "at least you've had the good sense to get it checked and that increases your odds of being in the better half of the 50 - 50". I genuinely thought I was doomed.  I think that's why I stick around.  There are other explanations for lumps and wonkiness. Okay in the end I did have some small areas of invasive disease within the huge area of DCIS but it could have been a lot worse, given the length of time it was left. My GP said I was like a large ship with a small hole and I wasn't going to be sinking any time soon. Despite the 'large' I did find it reassuring We have to be vigilant, it's our bodies, our health, we are just numbers to the health service. Anyway, even if it is cancer they'll sort it out. The team were so cheerful when they told me I 'only' had DCIS, that was very weird, of course I realise now why they were so happy. I wasn't going to sue them, jokes, they were happy for me, at least I think that's what it was. click the link under the panda, there's some nice pics illustrating the cells Carolyn xxx
Posts.Title: Urgent referral

Posts.Content: hi alli1970  welcome to the online community I had a mastectomy with immediate implant recon July 2015, had lots of seroma, scar wouldn't heal, lots of antibiotics, the scar was also untidy and had 'dog ears'. The implant was also way too big.  I needed a bit more surgery for a 2nd tumour so I asked for the implant to be swapped for a smaller one and the scar to be tidied up. 2nd op was much better, healed within a week, very little seroma, implant more suitable size, scar a lot nicer, not so scary when I catch sight of it in the mirror. I've been to the beach in bikinis several times and am really happy with the results. However I did used to swim and dive to a reasonable level and still like to have a go, I'm 54 but my son thinks I still dive pretty well, the implant caused quite a lot of drag and I did wonder how I would have coped without recon.  Obviously I'm not getting any younger and won't be going back to competitive diving but it was the first time I'd even thought about it. I thought about it the other day too but I remembered my surgeon saying he didn't want to go smaller as he was planning to 'even me up' at some point and he felt he could do a better job with the one he's used. A friend had just had a mastectomy with no recon and her scar was very neat and tidy but she was unhappy that she hadn't been offered, she's now having an expander and then implant. In my case, I felt I was being railroaded a bit, I know things do seem to happen very fast when you're diagnosed but nobody asked me if I wanted recon, everyone assumed I did, it was one of the first things my GP said to me, they do marvelous reconstructions these days. Posts.Title: Latimmus flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: hi Sally I wasn't really given a choice, which is just as well, I am terrible at making up my mind. The hospital where I was originally diagnosed had very few options but were happy to refer to wherever I preferred. I opted for the Royal Marsden in Chelsea and their preference is for immediate reconstruction. Although my initial diagnosis was DCIS it was a large area and had been lingering for a while so I chose implant reconstruction with the possibility to review that at a later date. It's the least invasive option, quickest and simplest of the procedures etc. There were a couple of things I wasn't happy with but overall I would recommend it. Pros -  it's quick and gets it out of the way and you don't have a phase where you have no breast which is an obvious reminder that you've had a mastectomy. Cons -  it is still a major operation and it takes time to recover. I think that because everyone was saying it's quick and simple and I was only staying in overnight I'd be right as rain in a few days and of course I wasn't. That's about managing my expectations as much as anything. The first implant was also too large but that's been replaced and now it's fine. I had to have revision surgery as there was some residual tumour that needed to be removed, although it was successfully treated with chemo and I asked for a smaller implant at that surgery. The 2nd surgery settled down a lot quicker, I had much less seroma and I healed a lot quicker. Overall I think I would recommend immediate recon.  The negatives I experienced was mostly down to my own expectations. Does that help ?   Feel free to ask for more information, I don't mind sharing and I know it all seems like you're being rushed into things, everything happens so quickly. xx Carolyn

Posts.Title: Breast lump over 50

Posts.Content: 15 years, how annoying I'm plodding my way to the magical five at the moment but struggling to see past that.  Did you have chemo last time?  As I understand it a lot will depend on how they stage it. A recurrence in the axilla isn't necessarily classed as 'stage 4' from all I've read over the last four years, so it is a watching and waiting game for now, along with all the anxiety that brings. If it is still classed as a primary site, lymph node spread is allowed in that criteria, then they may offer the full on chemo regime , again, if you did have it the first time. This will still be with the intent to cure you.  If it is deemed to have spread outside the lymph system in close proximity to the breast they may decide to offer you chemo to keep it under control, which will be a long term plan, this will also depend on whether it's Her2+++ or ER+ or TNBC.  There's quite a lot of variables involved.  It's also up to you, to a certain extent, which options you choose to accept. Which will depend on your age and circumstances.  If I get a local recurrence or another primary in the other breast, at 56 I'm probably going to accept another six months of chemo, with the hope I'd get 10 - 15 years, that'd be quite nice and with that to look forward to, it'd make the chemo more bearable.  Have you considered what you want to do? Carolyn xxx

Posts.Title: Senital node biopsy

Posts.Content: hi Jj1  mistymoley  is right, you will need to find some distractions.  I worry that if I don't worry I'll have something to worry about. However, in my experience, the team react when they see something and action things immediately. Remembering back to non routine mammograms I was directed to ultrasound straight away rather than being told to get dressed and go home. In the future, and I realise this won't help you now, all hospitals should follow this procedure : first annual mammogram AND ultrasound ( I believe you should have both) attend mammogram for good breast and move to ultrasound for implant reconstruction and follow up ultrasound for good breast, so mammogram good side, ultrasound both. This way you get to quiz the radiologist on what he or she is looking at and if they're seeing anything suspicious. ALERT: radiologists tend to be brutally honest. We have had some ladies ranting about not being given results over the phone - I know why they do and I also know why they don't. For me this time, my first mammogram, I was told that it absolutely wasn't a problem if I called in for results as the team had been cleared to tell me over the phone. Primarily this was because my onco was away on holiday and she didn't see that I should have to wait more than two weeks to get the results. As it turned out, I knew, because I'd asked on the day, that there was nothing to worry about, then the BCN matron emailed me, within the week,  to tell me the reports were 'all clear'. Then yesterday I did have the follow up results meeting as a formality. For a very brief moment or two it did occur to me that something might have been uncovered but it wasn't a fraught fortnight. This seems to be the kindest most practical solution to this particular part of the process and we could take action as a group to make sure it does happen. Gold star treatment for everyone and no more fraught fortnights, not for the first annual mammo anyway. Carolyn x

Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: Thanks for pointing this out Amy, I'm one of those people and I hadn't considered your viewpoint at all SORRY profuse apologies, to you and anyone else in that situation. Personally, I wanted to avoid chemo and felt that a 50-50 chance was pretty good, as that was what surgery alone offered. But everyone thought I was bonkers. The onco threatened to lock me in the room until I agreed to it. Eventually I accepted that 30% uplift was a significant improvement. Even with the overall risk of death from chemotherapy, generally, being 10%. That's 10% of all patients undergoing chemotherapy for all cancers. And it is usually patients with other health issues but not always. The best explanation I heard was when I went for a nuchal fold scan when pregnant with my son, my 4th, at 38. The results came back as very low risk BUT as the doctor pointed out, you can be deemed to be very low risk but you still might fall into that very small percentage. The test was simply a guide. For me, now, the stats say 80% survival with no recurrence to 5 years but I have to accept that I can still be in the 20%, even after all the treatment I've had, there's  no absolute guarantees. The stats are merely a guide. Chemo administered post surgery is usually 'belt and braces'. Some women only get a 1 or 2% uplift in survival stats from it and in my opinion, I wouldn't put myself through it. The uplift would have to be nearer the 10% risk factor. It also doesn't actually mean that you are in the 10% by default, you can still be in the 90%, because, for you, the surgery alone could be sufficient. There will always be someone that's had the surgery, and all the chemo and hormone therapies but still gets a recurrence within 5 years. I'll try and add this into my 'pep' talks from now on. Let me know if it makes sense, please Carolyn x

I discussed this with my young and fit echocardiologist, and we agreed that if I'd walked in, slightly out of breath and not too cheerful he'd have been concerned about my overall health and in his speciality he'd have take a bit of an extra look to double check. As it was, I waltzed in, asked him if he'd been on holiday or back to Portugal , since he looked a bit more tanned, began to strip before he'd bothered to close the curtain, what's the point in being modest, he's going to be rubbing lube into my chest in any case, and he'd be amazed if he found anything wrong with me, he's still going to be vigilant but he gets an overall picture. At the mammogram in 2012 the lady who was operating the xray machine took one look at my breasts and pursed her lips, she was the one who should have reported the scans, the slight anomaly would never have got past her, she would have double checked. A new cancer or recurrence or even mets can be quite active in 12 months without really showing symptoms and we're never really sure if that slight twinge is the same as yesterdays slight twinge or was it that twinge from last week ??? Especially as we're quite likely to want to bury our heads in the sand and pretend it's not happening to avoid getting on the merry go round again. rant over Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi Daisylou2  did your oncologist tell you where he got his 3% from ???   I've been looking around for a good figure. The overall risk is 10% but that is ALL cancers and ALL patients. Clearly cancer types and your own situation play a part in whether that is actually the risk for you. I was told that for breast cancer patients the risk was considerably lower and one of the reasons was that we are an easier group to manage, we turn up to our appointments, we take our meds and we look out for risk factors. I'd been guessing at 5%, or half that of the overall.  3% is a good figure to work with as a lot of women are cited as a 3% uplift in outcomes and obviously a 3% uplift versus a 3% risk is actually, no benefit. In fact I think I did say on one thread it was the 3% gang that needs a specific line of support because it's such a difficult decision to make. fingers crossed your score is low Carolyn xx

Posts.Title: One year on and 1st mamograme

Posts.Content: that explanation in one thread : when I was first diagnosed they could only find DCIS, the earliest stage of breast cancer, effectively stage 0, I'd never even heard of it. So they weren't considering chemo, DCIS doesn't respond to chemo, on the whole. But I had a large area that wasn't possible to give a good aesthetic result with a lumpectomy so mastectomy was the consensus. Surgery is by far and away the most effective cure for breast cancer, as with a lot of cancers. Post mastectomy I knew there was a risk of finding invasive breast cancer cells within the breast tissue under the microscope, and I would therefore be upgraded / downgraded depending on your viewpoint. Risk is about 25%. There are two main types of breast cancer, invasive ductal and invasive lobular  (lobular also has an in situ link) The breast tissue is tested for a range of things like how fast the cells are growing and how poorly they are differentiated from normal cells, that gives you your grade, low, medium and high (sometimes 1,2 and 3), and how large the affected area or tumour is and whether it's spread gives you the stage, 0,1,2,3,4.  (sometimes referred to as TNM  link ) They also check for hormone receptors and the human growth hormone, Her2.  (FISH) These results give you your profile, ER positive or negative, PR positive or negative, ER and PR positive, Her2 positive (Her2+++) or negative. Some people are triple positive and some triple negative. ER and PR positive cancers are treated with hormone therapy, Tamoxifen, Anastrozole or Letrozole. Sometimes chemotherapy is recommended, if there's node involvement or multiple tumours, large tumours, but if you have a smallish tumour with no node involvement chemotherapy offers little benefit, 1 or 2% and chemo carries a 10% risk, that's for ALL cancers, ALL patients, much lower for breast cancer because we're easier to manage as a group, we turn up for appointments, we take our medications, we check our temp. and take more precautions against infections. It is for each individual to assess their own risk v benefit , with their specialist teams. Her2+++ are treated with the monoclonal antibody Herceptin or Trastuzumab.  And also , so I'm told, always chemo. no choice. My Her2 score was high +++ and I'm also PR and ER negative. About 20% of breast cancers are Her2+++. The chemotherapy regime I was put on was for stage 3 cancers, they threw the kitchen sink at me. But I'm still here  yay ! I think triple negative also always demands chemotherapy as there are not yet any longer term therapies available to help prevent recurrence. Although, as I said, surgery is by far and away the most effective treatment for breast cancer. I guess I should acknowledge the use of the "Idiots Guide'   thanks guys more 'Idiots Guide' titles are available from all good book stores Carolyn xxx

Posts.Content: okay I'm going to say this out loud everyone thinks I'm going to die my husband included it comes out in funny ways, only my daughter says out loud "please don't die yet, mum". everyone knows someone who has died from cancer, both my husbands parents had bowel cancer that was poorly diagnosed and treated, my mother had leukaemia that was missed for several years, a school friend had breast cancer in her 30's and eventually succumbed to a secondary infection at 48 and a half. I think in our minds we replay those scenarios and the conclusion is death. My cousin said she was worried about seeing me in case I looked ill. Her brother died of liver cancer in 2012. We all die at some point and as we know Brits don't deal with death at all well. My husband hasn't visited a doctor for many years and is a typical head in the sand type of guy.  He says things like, if you drink that glass of wine it will all come back, or eat that cheese sandwich, or dye my hair, or whatever it is he sees me doing and it is literally everything and anything. I realise he's scared I'm going to die, so am I. Actually, I'm only scared of dying before I'm ready to go. I don't want to die yet. I have a few things I'd like to do first, like swim in the Indian Ocean, visit one of those big cat sanctuaries and play with baby tigers, visit China and see pandas ... lie in the sun and do nothing at all then fall into a swimming pool to cool off, you know, stuff, that stuff we all want to do one day but think we have plenty of time I'm going to eat the cheese and drink the wine while I still can For now, the husband seems happy cleaning the kitchen with those products I'm allergic to. He won't discuss it, it's pointless trying to encourage him to but I am trying to book a nice holiday, which initially he was reluctant to involve himself in but I've modified the package several times and he seems quite keen now. small steps and all that. good luck and keep talking, even if it's only about the weather,  we're all comfortable talking about the weather. x x x

Posts.Content: hi Welshie007  welcome to the online community, I hope you're finding your way around okay The 'F' element of your chemo is not essential nowadays and I would certainly ask for that to be taken off your prescription next round. My onco said "nobody uses F any more' and Sarah also had it removed from her regime after we talked about that. Obviously if you change more than one thing you don't really know what's working and what isn't so do try that first. In the meantime chemo is pretty brutal. You need to stay hydrated and that's difficult when you don't feel like moving let alone getting up to go to the loo all the time. You need to eat when you may not feel like it. And not just toast. And you need to rest. There are quite a few options on pain relief, did your GP offer anything slightly stronger? I swear by DHC (Dihydrocodeine) as it just suited me better than anything else but if your headaches are worse in the evenings it sort of sounds like you need to rest, I used Oxazepam to help me settle or Lorazepam, is more popular, they only give you a few but since you get free prescriptions it's not a problem, other than keep having to go to the pharmacy. Carolyn xxx
Posts.Title: Hellish Headache

Posts.Content: hi Caitlin59  the others are very amusing and part of me can find it funny now but I found it quite alarming. I found that I'd complete a task and think I'd done it perfectly well but a week or two later I'd be looking at the overall tasks and I'd find a swathe of errors, nothing earth shattering but weird things. I think I'd started a task and then thought I'd completed but actually hadn't. It's the only explanation I can think of. My brain would think the task through but my brain to hand co-ordination hadn't quite got there. The really odd thing I found was that when making payments to suppliers I print a copy for my records, as is prudent, but I found two copies of 5 payments pdfs in the folder, I immediately panicked and went back online to check but I clearly hadn't paid everyone twice. I still have no idea what I did or how this happened but it's not the only 'chemo brain' instance. There were quite a few. I was advised not to make any important decisions whilst on chemo, that was my marvelous oncologist who said that. I think she described it as 'not being my sharpest' ... you can say that again. Around about April / May time, 5 months post chemo,  I truly was feeling a lot better but when I look back now there were still times when my brain was not all there, several sandwiches short of a picnic and all those other lovely analogies. My advice would be double check every single thing methodically, which I'm sure you do anyway, I'm not trained in any form of accounting, I just have to do it because it's my company, but on the important stuff we do have our accounts company and our invoices out is done by a freelancer / self employed accounts lady. I wasn't running the risk of pissing of the HMRC but could have easily annoyed a few people. This is the kind of thing you need to be aware of and vigilant against. hope that helps Carolyn x

Posts.Title: IDC with Medullary type Features

Posts.Content: I agree with what Elle said I always seem to catch something on planes, aviation flu I call it. Anything from a runny nose to full on sinus inflammation. I flew in Feb after finishing chemo on Christmas Eve, what's that, 5 weeks post chemo ? I had no hair when I arrived and a 5 o'clock shadow on my head about a week later.  I also had the runniest nose I'd had in a long time after the flight which developed from day 4 and left me a bit knackered for the last couple of days. Got through 10 packs of travel tissues. Nobody stopped me in customs or passport control, only issue was I was going to do full hair (wig) and makeup on the way to the airport but it was dark and then we seemed to fast track through, got to searching and the lady asked me to remove my bobble hat, my face must have told a story because she instantly softened and just had a quick feel around the edges. to be honest the Feb trip was a bit soon, we didn't have the best weather, two of the kids came to keep an eye on me but then I'm mum again and that's always a juggling act. I had surgery when I got back, March 8th. I much preferred my May/June trip to Sardinia on my own.  After being mum for 30 years it was bliss. I got up when I wanted, I went to bed when I felt like it, 9pm or 1am.  I ate what I liked, when I liked.  I hired a little car and drove around to different beaches and had an absolutely marvelous time. I only speak a tiny amount of Italian but managed to communicate, even in the tiny shop that sold the most delicious parma ham I've ever tasted along with some delicious tomatoes. By May/June I was 5 months past chemo, had some hair which I'd dyed brown and nobody really noticed that i'd been ill. Although I did try to get a specific room with sunshine to avoid having to sit by the pool if I didn't feel like it, but as it turned out it was fine, nobody gave my fake boob a second glance. Funniest thing for me was seeing the difference in the type of men who talk to you when you have long hair as opposed to short styles. Give it some careful consideration, there's no point rushing recovery at this stage Carolyn xx Always Baking

Posts.Content: hi Patricia 61  welcome to the online community sorry you've had to find your way here, it's all a bit of a shock when we're first diagnosed, I felt I was asking the same questions over and over and they'd tell me things and I'd forget. I had an MRI scan but it was reported twice and one report showed a 2nd lesion, the other report didn't. My original biopsy only showed DCIS too. I now realise how important it is to have as much information as possible before you act on it. I was told I could safely have a mastectomy with immediate implant reconstruction as I 'only' had DCIS, when in fact that wasn't the case, my private consultant had indicated that although they had only found DCIS they'd only taken three small samples and post surgery pathology could reveal invasive cancer and then they'd have to do more tests, and that's what they did. Thankfully nothing was found on my chest, abdomen and pelvis scan, or CAP scan, or my bone scan but then my MRI had shown something to one doctor and not to another. Your team sound like they are being vigilant and that's good. If they know exactly what they are dealing with they can treat you more accurately. What time do you have to be at the hospital ? I was told to be there at 7 am but I got there early, as did all the others who were showing up for their surgeries, it's nerve wracking.  Will you have someone with you ? hugs Carolyn xx

Posts.Title: Operation

Posts.Content: hi Bjez I thought my oncologist was on top of things but TCHP seems to be the new standard for Her2+++ breast cancers. I had 4 doses of EC, epirubicin and cyclophosphamide, the EC of FEC, every three weeks and then 4 doses of accelerated T every two weeks, with the Herceptin being introduced with the T. The Perjeta combination came in during the last year I think. I'd have felt happier with it but we'll just have to see how it goes. Anyway, I'm a complete wimp and I got through it. Veins were a problem and we all agreed pretty quickly that I needed a PICC line and after that it was a breeze.  As Julia said, drink plenty it really does help. They gave me a lorazepam tablet for the PICC line, they don't like you jumping around, that's one of the anxiety meds that's metabolised in the gut rather than the liver and I'm thinking these will be okay to take in advance of the chemo. LOT, is the way to remember them, Lorazepam, Oxazepam and Temazepam. Since you're on free prescriptions your GP should have no issue with giving you a few to get you through this week. I was really lucky with side effects and didn't have any infections, in fact with my wig on most people didn't even realise I was being treated. the constipation v diarrhea balancing act was the trickiest part All in all I'd say it's the waiting that's the worst, the day itself was a bit of an anticlimax, the doctor took an age to clear the drugs and give me one last pep talk so it was getting quite late, so we scrapped the idea of the cold cap and frankly I was relieved I didn't have to 'give it a go'. anything else just shout : ) Carolyn xx

Posts.Content: hi all vitamin and mineral deficiencies are complex and not really that well documented. I had low potassium which was picked up in the routine bloods. I was asking to see them out of curiosity. Anyway, most of us know that bananas are a reasonably good source of potassium but the nurse said she'd rather have me take the supplement they'd prescribed for the 3 days then I could follow my own plans. When I looked it up on Boots Web Md I found that low potassium is linked to 'close motor control' which I happened to be suffering with, I only noticed when I struggled to pick up a bar of chocolate. It is this kind of side effect and remedy that is poorly documented and well worth us comparing our notes as a self help mechanism. I noticed that the NHS  sites only give 'overdose' indications, not deficiency, I've no idea how many people overdose on copper in the UK? www.nhs.uk/.../Other-vitamins-minerals.aspx

Posts.Title: DIEP resulting in smaller boobs than before

Posts.Content: hi RosemarieC  when I was told I needed chemotherapy I didn't know anyone who had survived cancer after having chemo so I was completely freaking out. Firstly surgery is by far and away the most effective treatment for breast cancer, may I ask which type of breast cancer you had, I say 'had' because it's gone now, since you had a lumpectomy. I needed chemo because I had Her2+ breast cancer which is a bit sneaky and doesn't respond to any of the hormone inhibitors. I had EC and T and I wasn't sick at all although I did have diarrhea but they have good meds for all the side effects. The 'E' component is Epirubicin and it does make your hair fall out but I got myself a nice wig and practiced painting eyebrows with my Bobbi Brown eyebrow kit. The other thing with breast cancer chemo is that the steroids they give you make you hungry and a lot of people put on weight rather than lost it. Since volunteering here I realise that chemotherapy does have a vital part to play in treating cancers but not all cancers require chemotherapy. Have you got friends and family around you ? My daughter made me check my temperature five times a day. xxx Carolyn xx

Posts.Title: Breast lump biopsy

Posts.Content: hi Violet25  I can hear something I can relate to and it's about overall body image rather than specific cup sizes When I was told I was going to need a mastectomy I wanted to take my boobs, the only part of my body I was remotely comfortable with, for one final beach holiday to mourn their loss, to bid farewell to my life as it was, to grieve for my body that would never be the same again and it is a situation where grief is an appropriate word I heard the stages of grief listed a few years ago, not in a cancer context but it made perfect sense shock, disbelief and denial, followed by sadness and anger, blaming and bargaining and then a gradual acceptance  I have accepted my new fake boob largely because the first surgery resulted in something quite hideous and this is much better. I'm going to advocate a delayed reconstruction for you, I think it makes much more sense.  Take time to accept the diagnosis first, let your body heal after all the treatment , get well again and then make decisions on the cosmetics.  I had an immediate implant reconstruction to give me a breast shape and it works in a bikini, I've taken it out to the beach a few times and I'm happy with it.  I may decide that I want something more natural at some point but then again, now I've had a chance to accept it, I may not. yours sincerely  wonky fake barbie tit  Carolyn xxxxx

Posts.Content: hi Tetleysscooby   that's a lot to take in. it's a good thing you noticed the slight indent, I had always had lumpy breasts and had been reassured many times that there was nothing sinister going on but then I had a bout of stress and approaching 50 started to feel the first indications of menopause but every time I went to the doctor it was always my hormones or my age and I left feeling reassured. Eventually I booked myself a private mammogram and what a shock, the radiologist showed me the mammogram as he was doing the ultrasound, that's standard if you go privately by the way, it's a better gauge of what's going on, and there on the screen he measured out 75mm ... yes a whopping 75mm, that's like a tennis ball.  I felt so stupid that I couldn't feel anything but he said it was flat, not a lump, the only 'lump' I could feel was the edge of it, once it was so big it was poking out the side of my boob.  I had truly pestered my GP, looking back, I'd never been to see him then went 20 times in a few months. Then the results came back as DCIS, which is very early stage breast cancer and is 'just' treated with a mastectomy. Everyone was so blasé about that too. it was 'only' DCIS and I'd 'only' need a mastectomy. great. and why were they all smiling.  ???? I was furious that my routine mammogram had missed the start of this cancer back in 2012 but truly grateful that it hadn't spread. While I was waiting for my results all I could find was anything over 50mm was either stage 3 or stage 4, I felt doomed. Although the DCIS was then really good news, for me it really wasn't.  And besides I was then found to have invasive Her2+++ cancer after my mastectomy, so had to go through all the staging scans and eventually was right back to the original stage 3 or 4 but thankfully it's not spread. Rollercoaster is a really fitting term. I think it's harder for people watching us go through it, I was so glad it was me and not one of my kids . Keep talking to your partner and keep him involved, there's usually some decisions to be made or research that can be done. I had to have an MRI after the original round of mammograms, ultrasounds and biopsies. It all helps get a better picture of what we're dealing with. please stick to the tried and trusted web sites for info, like Macmillan, Cancer Research UK and Breast Cancer Care Carolyn x
Posts.Title: I'm 43 saw a dimpling on the breast and went for a routine referr...

Posts.Content: hi Dee KiwiCardi  I complained via their website [The Royal Marsden.], they have a 'complaints, compliments and feedback' area, with an online form. at the first attempt I probably rambled on too much but ]they] called me straight away to try and clarify what was wrong and what could be done about it. He recommended writing down what my issues were and what I'd like done about it, they like a quick solution that you'll be happy with. You have two issues,correct me if I'm wrong at any point ... one is the PICC or portacath, personally my PICC was absolutely fine, I had no issues with it and I can highly recommend it as an alternative to cannulation. Secondly you are experiencing delays and you are due to have herceptin which means you're Her2+++ , correct ? Say you are finding the waiting incredibly stressful and you just need to find out what's taking so long, or words to that effect. At least then they'll have a chance to either explain their reasoning for the delays or act and get you in quicker. Some tests do take time and, much as we love to believe we're the top priority, the hospital has to function and schedules can be tricky to manage. However there are guidelines and limits for waiting for treatment. let me know if that sounds reasonable ? by the way, training is an ongoing problem in a lot of hospitals, they just don't have enough staff to keep the place running smoothly, so I don't think we can view training on the portacath as a quick fix solution.  One of my nurses, has been training for over  a year now and has only just graduated to inserting cannulas, it'll be another 6 months before he's close to using the PICC lines. Carolyn x

Posts.Content: hi all I'm similar to Fandango as I had a large area of DCIS but I WAS warned by my private consultant that I may be upgraded after the surgery, the London NHS team then pretty much scorned that advice and told me I wasn't urgent as it was only DCIS. It does seem to vary how they share this information . It took me a while to find it but the risk is apparently 20%, I was slightly more likely to be in the 20% because I knew I'd had my suspicious area for more than 3 years. I was found to have invasive Her2+ and was told they always recommend chemo for that and I'm ER -  so no hormone inhibitors. IF you do have invasive areas in the DCIS and it is ER+ then you'll be offered tamoxifen or similar and these are very effective at preventing recurrence and spread. You may be offered chemotherapy as well. IF you have Her2+ or triple negative invasive components they like you to have chemotherapy as it reduces the risk of recurrence or spread. I had 4 rounds of EC which is Epirubicin and Cyclophosphamide , every three weeks and then 4 rounds of accelerated T every two weeks with Herceptin every three weeks. I was dreading it but I survived and it wasn't actually as bad as I thought it might be. It took me a couple of weeks to get a grip on the idea and I did ask around, trying to find trying to find reassurances that not having chemo was a better idea. Eventually my oncologist held my hand and said, I'd not be advising this if I didn't think it was the right thing for you. hugs Carolyn xxx
Posts.Title: Cant seem to get answer from my What if question...

Posts.Content: hi Sharpie6  I had a terrible time routine mammogram missed a tumour in 2012, even though i'd had loads of mammograms because my boobs were lumpy and dense. paid for  private screen but it was all highly suspicious so I was advised to go back into NHS for MRI biopsy only showed DCIS or non life threatening non urgent pre cancerous cells. MRI report was done twice, first by private guy, who picked up the 2nd lesion,  and then by the Royal Marsden in London, the 'top' cancer hospital, who didn't.  Surgeon marked up boob and I took the trouble to point out the 2nd lesion which was now an obvious lump in my chest, not even obscured by boob  post op discovered that the surgeon had missed the 2nd tumour completely.  post op histopathology showed Her2+++ and then everything suddenly became very urgent indeed as I was sent for staging scans that I was told I wouldn't need and then on to oncology  so yes, a catalogue of errors from top professionals  only here today because I made a fuss and raised a complaint  Carolyn xx
